item.title: Myth of indian box office
item.dc:creator: sanjeevnjha
item.content:encoded:
Myth Of Khans and Indian Box Office A common known fact that is stated again and again in Indian Media is that the Khans are more popular than Hollywood stars like Tom cruise and Johny Depp. It is said that khans have huge fan follwing (more than 3 billion as per some die hard fans) and pull more people to cinema halls than their hollywood rivals. We at 4 Bubbles decided to investigate the truth of above statements and came up with some shocking results. Comparison of Top 5 domestic grosers of Bollywood and Hollywood   Top 5 Domestic grossers of hollywood in 2011    

  Assumed Data The population of USA is 312848000 Avg Ticket Price 7.96 USD How calculation is done If you divide the total domestic gross by Average ticket price you will get the number of people in USA who watched the movie in cinema halls. Simple Maths! So even the number 5 domestic grosser Pirates of the Caribbean: On Stranger Tides is watched by more than 3 Crore people in movie halls in USA. The total population of USA is 312848000. It means that close to 10 percent (9.6 to be exact) of american population watched the latest Johny Depp movie in halls. Please check the below links that are used for data like average ticket price,box office gross and country population. Sources http://boxofficemojo.com/yearly/chart/?yr=2011 http://www.natoonline.org/statisticstickets.htm http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/List_of_countries_by_population   Now take a look at top 5 indian dometic grossers.  

    Asumed Data Average ticket price as Rs 100 Population of india is  1,210,193,422   How calculation is done Same as Above Sources http://www.imdb.com/list/obEPEB8JnDk/ http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/List_of_countries_by_population   Verdict The truth is that the Harry Potter movie is pulling close to 5 crore people to movie halls in a country of just above 30 crore population while our film stars fail to pull even one and half crore people to cinema halls in a country of more than one billion. It is time to accept defeat. Question for Salman Fans? So the mass hero or dabangg khan or khan with most loyal following or in his fan's words: "Only one with the ability to generate hysteria" really has any mass following ? We have only one question for salman's fans :" If a guy barely pulls 1 percent of indians to cinema halls ,what kind of hysteria he generates or the rest of india(99 %) does not matter"?   What if Khans has same appeal as Hollywood Stars If a hindi movie attracts 15.2% of public to cinema halls like Harry Potter at the average ticket price of Rs 100 than its domestic gross will be Rs 18,39,49,40,000. Even if top guys like shahrukh,aamir and salman has following like Johny Depp (No 5 on list),their film should earn Rs 11617856851 The truth is ,india is in true need of a star,director or script writer who can crack the 1000 crore collection.Till then there are no superheroes. Period. Now time to expose the overseas King People say Shahrukh Khan has great following overseas and his latest film Don 2 has blockbuster overseas collection of 12 million US dollars. Great,isn't it? But How many people watched this shahrukh khan hit movie Don 2 outside india. Lets assume the average ticket price as 4 USD .Fair enough.12,0,00,000/4 =3,000000.So 30 lakh people watches a shahrukh khan movie outside india.So a heartthrob of Billions Mr Shahrukh Khan's Don 2 is watched by mere 3 million people outside india. Compare this with MI 4.In india It has a total collection of 35 crores.It means that this movie was watched by 35 lakhs indians in India alone. MI 4 has total Overseas collection of 301,057,680 UD and even at the average ticket price of 4 USD ,number of people who watched this Cruise movie outside usa are  301,057,680/4=75264420.So more than 7 crore people watches MI 4 outside USA including the 35 lakhs inside india only while the badshah's superhit movie Don 2 is watched by just 30 lakh people outside india. Don 2 has another joke of a record : Highest single day gross of 82000 USD in Australia.Average ticket price in autralia is 8 USD .So a total of 10,250 people watched Don 2 in autralia on its biggest day. In comparison,MI 4 earned 20 crore in India in first weekend of 5 days.SO a total of 20 lakh (2000000) indians watched MI 4 in 5 days.That is,An average of 4 lakh indians per day in india.   Are Hollywood Movies threat to Indian Film Industry? The answer is a Big Yes.The collection of MI 4 in india is 35 crore.It is one third of don 2's collection in India and that too at a limited release. Sources http://boxofficeindia.com/overdetail.php?page=shownews&articleid=3916&nCat= http://boxofficereport.net/mission-impossible-4-india-lifetime-collections/ http://www.hindustantimes.com/Entertainment/Bollywood/Don-2-earns-Rs-48-cr-in-opening-weekend/Article1-787344.aspx

wp:comment.wp:comment_content: Remarkable page, I will be viewing back again usually to hunt for fresh news.
2 observations a) any time I've watched a movie in the US I've rarely seen the theater even half full. b) your calculations don't account for repeat viewers

the real comparison is between the number of people who can afford a movie ticket in the US and India?
how many in India can afford the 100 rupee ticket? the us ticket price is the minimum hourly wage in the country. the indian one is greater than the daily wage.
you do the math!

item.title: Five Movies to watch on this weekend
item.dc:creator: sanjeevnjha
item.content:encoded:
Recommending a list of movies can be a problematic enterprise. First you have this problem of inadequate information. You can draw up a list today and realize years later that you included rip offs. A long long  time ago, in the era of black and white telly and before the advent of Cable TV and the Internet,  I saw a movie called "Ek Ruka hua Faisla". I was impressed with the script, I was impressed by the brilliant director. What a movie, I said and  recommended that movie to plenty of people.  25 years after first watching this movie on TV, I bought a movie DVD, called "Twelve Angry Man". I saw "Twelve angry man"  and realized that "Ek Ruka Hua Faisla" was nothing but a shameless rip off.  Now I do not advise anyone to watch it. A bloody shameless, pathetic,  blatant rip off without any imagination. Likewise, Aamir Khan managed to screw "on the waterfront" beyond any chances of redemption. People who have Ghulam on their watch list can safely tick it off.   Also, people have very different tastes depending on their age, gender, social graph and location. Movie tastes also evolve over time depending on what you have already seen and who you interact with. I was a big fan of Rambo I, Rambo II and Rambo III when I was sixteen and before I learnt english and saw other movies. I could watch DDLJ once but today it would be very hard for me to sit through a Karan Johan escapade to dream land where everything is pink and air is redolent with love. As a kid you are more impressionable and watch your movies with more attention. For many in my generation steven Spielberg would remain the best director ever because he gave us Indiana Jones and Jurassic Park. There may have been better movies than Indiana Jones but I was not there and I was not waiting for them all summer. We have a sweet spot for things that we did as a teenager or naive romantic. There are very few work of art that truly transcend time. Rest all are part of fashion. Rajesh Khanna may have stopped traffic in his times but I will never take notice of him. We do not want to recommend "grand" or art house movies as well. Everyone knows about La Dolce Vita, Psycho and Bicycle Thief. So many key strokes have already been wasted, what is the point of adding few more? They are already on everyone's must watch list. On the other hand it is impossible to get a copy of european art house movies. There may be a solid movie out there but not in your own language. So making a list of true art house movies runs the risk of excluding an audience due to procurement difficulties. Let's face it, I am not a critic and neither are you. The camera may have shown legs for the first time in "Citizen Kane" but you and I may not like it, it is too dated for us. At the same time I was hopelessly in love with Pooja Bhat of Sadak.  I do not like African Queen or Maltese Falcon even a wee bit despite having a dashing Humphrey bogart . You get my gist. And finally I have my personal biases. The insider has 8.0 rating on IMDB but I do not like it. I do not have a reason. Al Pacino, Russell Crowe, a big budget, I should like it, right? But I do not. Now probably is the right time to bring out my five movie recommendations. Remember, all my recommendations suffer from my personal bias. The bright side is, I do not offer a critique's tale. I would just tell you, why I, a normal joe, love these movies. 1) 2001, A space Odyssey

  2001, A space Odyssey is a visual treat and nothing else. Do not watch this movie for story, script or plot continuity. Do not be baffled by what is happening. Do not even be fooled by stories of HAL 9000 and Dave conversation. The movie is slow and you should only watch it for sheer imagery. Man, it is difficult to believe Kubrick made this movie in 1968. Just try it in 2012 and it will not look even a bit dated. To me that is sheer talent. Wow, it is just so damn pleasing on eyes.The visual sophistication is just mind boggling. Also, for people seeking "meaning" there can be plenty. Carl Sagan talks about our bias of "humanoid" aliens in Cosmos and why we can only think of aliens as humans with green horns because that is all we know. Carl Sagan was an advisor for this movie and Kubrick never shows how aliens look. 2) Vertigo

Hitchcock was a master artist. As a good cinema goer, you need to see one Hitchcock caper. Just think of it, anyone who could have made Dial M for murder, Rear Window, Strangers on a Train, Vertigo, North By Northwest etc. must have had oodles of talent. However if there is just one HitchCock movie you can watch then it got to be "Vertigo". Vertigo has everything. A female fatale, mistaken identity, sexual innuendos, crazy camera angles and an afflicting condition. Here I also tend to agree with critiques (and that happens rarely)/ The best part of Hitchcock is that he will never hide the truth from you. You know what is happening before hand but still can watch the movie riveted to your seat. The theme has been copied numerous time in hindi movies like "Who Kaun Thi".   3) Body Double I would like to recommend Body double as an example of what true inspiration is. Taking something and providing your own point of view. Using the original as source of illumination and not as something to hang on to. When David Dhawan made partner, he hung onto Hitch in a shameless way. I doubt if you can call frame by frame copy as "inspired" (remember the scene where Salman puts a pen in Govinda's shirt?) Now Body double is a good example of inspiration. Brain de Palma takes elements from Rear window (voyeurism) , elements from Vertigo (following and locking lips with female fatale) and theme of Husband wanting to get rid of wife and comes up with a gem. The fact that you get to know of "Holly in Hollywood" is a bonus :) Brian de Palma is also the director of Mission impossible and it may surprise you that the famous "break into CIA" scene is a copy of an earlier movie. That famous scene where Tom cruise hangs from wires and Jean Reno is balancing him is "inspired" from the main heist scene of a movie called "Top-Kapi". If you watch the original then you will agree that Brian de Palma managed to up the scene a bit in Mission impossible. This I would quote as a good example of "inspiration" and not hindi "Partner"   4) Bitter Moon Bitter Moon is Polanski's less quoted movies but I would rate it very high. It deals with subjects of love. Have we all not , at some time, secretly harboured the worst feelings about the people we love? To begin with, the guy was madly in love with a girl. After the novelty of love wears off, he starts mistreating and openly humiliating her.  Anyone who have been in love and have experienced the highs and lows of it would love this movie Hugh Grant is plastic and just ignore him. Concentrate on peter coyote, he is just superb. For indians, there is Victor Banerjee though he has about four lines in the whole movie. 5) Amores Perros

We had a theory. Every movie director has three distinct phases. First phase is of hunger and struggle. You are an struggling  artist dying of hunger. You do not have resources but you have sheer talent. You manage to create something that does not have technical brilliance but has a "soul" that moves people. There are no big budgets to back your work and typically people notice you by word of mouth. Think of christian nolan and "memento". The only thing driving the work is your talent. Then you get noticed, you get lucky and you get resources. You can hire the best equipment and best names and you create something that marries your original creativity with technical brilliance brought on by availability of resources. This fusion of talent and resources gets commercial success as well as critique's acclaim. Third phase is when the original soul is lost and you are left with just resources and technical brilliance.  Your talent is some where buried under the mound of commercial success. The only thing driving your work is a huge advertising budget. No matter what people may say about Avaatar I do not think it comes anywhere near "Terminator-I" as far as a "soul" of movie is concerned. Amores Perros is a good example of Phase I where everything is driven by explosive talent and creative hunger. This is a mexican movie but you can get english subtitles easily. There are three stories and you can take your pick on what is best. This movie will stay with you for a long time. The dog fight scene, ramming of cars, A model losing her leg, A former revolutionary killing people for lunch. There are too many gripping scenes.

item.title: List of Players who never won a slam inspite of reaching multiple finals
item.dc:creator: sanjeevnjha
item.content:encoded: In the history of open era of tennis, Only eight players have never won a grand slam inspite of reaching multiple grand slam finals.We have left the players who have reached only one singles final in their career.   Steve Denton   In 1980's Denton was the fastest server in the world. In 1984, he set the world record of fastest serve (222 km/h).The record was later broken by Mark Philippoussis in 1997. He reached the finals of Australian open in 1981 and 1982 and lost both times to Johan Kriek. Results In Slam Finals 1981    Australian Open Johan Kriek   2–6, 6–7, 7–6, 4–6 1982    Australian Open Johan Kriek   3–6, 3–6, 2–6   Best Results Doubles champion at 1982 U.S. Open    Kevin Curren Another name to feature on the list is the doubles partner of Steve Denton. 1983 was the breakthrough year for Kevin Curren. He reached the semifinals of 1983 upsetting Jimmy Connors but he himelf lost to Chris Lewis in another upset. In 1984 he lost to  Mats Wilander in the final of Australian open.His best chance to win the slam came in wimbledon 1985. He defeated Stefan Edberg ,John McEnroe and Jimmy Connors on his route to final. The other finalist was an unknown 17 years old Boris Becker. Curren was huge favorite but the night belonged to Becker. Results In Slam Finals Runner-up      1984    Australian Open Grass   Mats Wilander 7–6(5), 4–6, 6–7(3), 2–6 Runner-up      1985    Wimbledon      Grass   Boris Becker  3–6, 7–6(4), 6–7(3), 4–6 Best Results career high rankings of world no 5 Winner of four Grand Slam doubles titles   Miloslav Mecir Pouparly known as the best of second bests of tennis.He was rebel,a loner,artist on the courts,and only player without a coach in 1980's. He was last player to use wooden racket in grand slam and that too in a final! He denied the career slam glory to Mats wilander in 1988 and earned the nickname swede killer. Unfortunately he never played his A game in the finals and lost both  times tamely to Ivan Lendl. Results In Slam Finals Runner-up      1986    US Open Hard    Ivan Lendl    4–6, 2–6, 0–6 Runner-up      1989    Australian Open Hard    Ivan Lendl    2–6, 2–6, 2–6 Best Results Winner of gold medal at 1988 seoul olympics career high rankings of world no 4   Cedric Pioline   Pioline was a grand slam material but Unfortunately he faced sampras in both slam finals he went to.Pete sampras was unbeatable on hard and grass courts between 1993 to 1997. Even Federer would have struggled to take a set from Sampras in those days. Results In Slam Finals Runner-up      1993    US Open Hard    Pete Sampras  4–6, 4–6, 3–6 Runner-up      1997    Wimbledon      Grass   Pete Sampras  4–6, 2–6, 4–6 Best Results Member of the French team that won the Davis  cup in 1996 and 2001   Todd Martin Martin was a very fine tennis player but unfortunately his career collided with the two all time greats of the game : Pete Sampras and Andre Agassi. Results In Slam Finals Runner-up      1994    Australian Open Hard    Pete Sampras  6–7(4–7), 4–6, 4–6 Runner-up      1999    US Open Hard    Andre Agassi  4–6, 7–6(7–5), 7–6(7–2), 3–6, 2–6 Best Results Member of the US team that won the Davis Cup in 1995   Alex Corretja Nobody can held a match point against sampras (US open (1996) in his prime without talent. Coretja had plenty of that.He was highly skillful player who can play almost every shot in tennis manual.He was the only clay court specialist between Borg and Nadal to play well on all surfaces.Unfortunately he lost both his slam finals. Results In Slam Finals 1998    French Open    Carlos Moya   3–6, 5–7, 3–6 2001    French Open    Gustavo Kuerten       7–6(7–3), 5–7, 2–6, 0–6 Best Results First man ever to win the Tour Championships (1998) without having previously won a Grand Slam tournament   Mark Philippoussis In 1996 he reached fourth round of Australian open upsetting Pete Sampras.In 1997 he recorded the fatest serve of 229 km/h.He was nicknamed scud because of his booming serve.On his day he was second to none but unfortunately those days were very few.In the end he was another example of tennis burnout. Results In Slam Finals Runner-up      1998    US Open Hard    Patrick Rafter 3–6, 6–3, 2–6, 0–6 Runner-up      2003    Wimbledon      Grass   Roger Federer 6–7(5–7), 2–6, 6–7 Best Results 1999 Won the Hopman Cup for Australia along with Jelena Dokic   Andy Murray The only active player on the list.He carries the hopes of a nation on his shoulders everytime he enters a slam.Despite a good game and amazing talent,he has so far failed to deliver the final punch in the slam final. All the other players on the list have reached exactly two finals in their playing career.Andy murray Fans can celebrate this fact as there is not even a single player in the open era who has not won a slam after reaching three finals.Oops,there is one,Andy Murray! Results In Slam Finals Runner-up      2008    US Open Hard    Roger Federer 2–6, 5–7, 2–6 Runner-up      2010    Australian Open Hard    Roger Federer 3–6, 4–6, 6–7(11–13) Runner-up      2011    Australian Open        Hard    Novak Djokovic 4–6, 2–6, 3–6

item.title: 12 Bollywood trivias
item.dc:creator: sanjeevnjha
item.content:encoded: 42 Kisses that happened before devika rani Released in 1932, Zarina was the first hindi movie to show on screen kiss. Actress Zubeida lip locked a total of 42 times in the movie and her name was a sensation across the country. First Silver Jubilee Released in 1934 , Baghdad Ka Chor was first silver jubilee Hindi movie. It was made my Kohinoor Company and in the same year they had another silver jubilee success in  Karna. Stardom bigger than Sridevi Madhuri and Hema Malini Sulochana (Ruby Myers) was first superstar actress. She was the first indian actress to buy a car (Chevrolet) and was also known as telephone girl because she worked in telephone exchange before joining the films. she used to draw a salary of Rs 5000 per month at the peak of her career . Rival to 3 idiot's hip shaped chairs One Sari stitched with rupee notes (worth Rs 1 lakh) was displayed across the halls to promote the movie Laila Majnu in 1930's . It was claimed that the heroine wears the same sari in movie. Many people just came to see the Sari! When Hollywood came to India The River(1951) was the first english movie to shoot its reels inside India.Many indian actors also acted in the movie. Russia without Raj Kapoor Pardeshi (1957) was the first Indo-Soviet Movie.Nargis and Oleg Streezhnov were the part of its star cast. Prithviraj kapoor was the part of star cast. It was a well made movie but it flopped in india. Actor with bigger commitment than Aamir khan in Ghulam Yehudi ki Ladki was released In 1930's and was a success at box office.The acting of nawab Kahmiri was praised by the public as well as the press.He removed all the 32 teeth from his mouth to look older for his part. The owner of New Theatre Paid him a bonus of Rs 3200(Rs 100 for each tooth). Thakrey is not the first guy to burn posters During the tour of Madhya Pradesh Vinoda Bhave saw a number of (so called) filthy cinema posters all over the city. He said to his followers,"They are an attack on our family life and culture and we must not tolerate such naked obscenities any more". After that all the posters were torn and burnt. History of talkie movies in india Melody of Love was the first talkie movie to be released in india in 1929. It served as a catalyst for Hindi talkies like Alam aara and and Shiri-Farhad. One tangewala sold his horse and watched Shiri-Farhad 32 times with his family. When Lovers locked horns In 1957 B.R. Chopra lodged a court case against Madhubala for Rs 30,000. Surprisingly ,Dilip Kumar acted as a witness for B.R. Chopra in the court. Later Madhubala claimed that Dilip Kumar wanted  to destroy her career and thus acted against her. Abroad study as a pill for love affair Dilip kumar was against the love affair between K. Asif and his sister Akhtar Khan. So Dileep sent Akhtar to Newyork for studies. Later in the same year Akhtar married K. Asif in London in a secret affair. This was the third marriage for K. Asif. He was earlier married to sitara devi and nigara sultana. Scandal that rocked the nation Roberto Rossellini was invited by Nehru to make a film on india .Here he met the writer Sulochana DasGupta. Sulochana had two children and she was pregnant with a third when she fall in love with Rossellini. Finally, Sulochana left India with her younger son and Rossellini. They were assisted by Jawaharlal Nehru and M.F. hussain in the escape. Later they married in Rome. Sulochana's husband Harisadhan Dasgupta lodged a police complaint.  To add a twist, Harisadhan was friend of Satyajit Roy.   Author : Leena Mehta Leena is MBA from reputed college and loves blogging in free time.

item.title: Mystery of Will part 2
item.dc:creator: sanjeevnjha
item.content:encoded:
Advocate took out one large black envelope from his briefcase and handed it to gautam.He said,"Please keep this.This is your property."Gautum studied the envelope carefully.It was sealed and nothing was written on either back or front side.He started to open it carefully with a paper knife. He had rage/amazement/indifference written all over his face once he glanced inside the envelope.He walked to the table and removed the bottle and bowl.He inverted the envelope and three paper slips fell on the table.He arranged the pieces on the table and tried to make sense out of this puzzle.Even advocate Kumar was shocked/confused by all the strange happenings.He slowly walked to the table and joined gautam.His bewildered look told the story.   1)An object crore times more valuable than :

2)Source of message whose other end ends in suspense. 3)There meet ET on CM's Gift.Go to western coast. Gautam tilted his head and asked,"Was he sane at the time of death?" Kumar replied,"Of course.He settled in kenya after leaving India.He was respected a lot in the indian community there.His lavish parties were talk of the town.Five years back,he invited our boss Amitesh Kumar to his house.There he gave him this envelope. ---How can you be so sure that he was rich at the time of death?You were not in kenya at that time,rite. -- Yes.But our fees for tansferring this envelope to you is Rs five crores. The word "Five crores" hit the kumar like a bullet.He continued to stare at Mr Kumar. Kumar continued,"Look at this document.This is the proof that we have handed the envelope to you.After you sign on this,we will fax this document to a Jamican bank and Rs five crore will be wired to our account.Everything was pre arranged."Gautam silently took the document and read it for five minutes and then placed his signature at the bottom.Advocate gleefully placed the signed document in his briefcase and departed.Gautam felt relieved to be alone.His mind was full of thoughts : -- One crore times valuable of what? -- What kind of message ends in suspense? -- How is ET and CM related together?

wp:comment.wp:comment_content: hello, superior article, and a good understand! 1 for my book marks.

item.title: Mystery of Will part 3
item.dc:creator: sanjeevnjha
item.content:encoded:
Gautam was sure about only one fact after the careful study of slips that first one is in sanskrit.He remembered his next door neighbour Desai.Desai has keen interest in collecting old sanskrit manuscripts.He pocketed all the slips and walked towards the house of Desai. Desai himself opened the door on the doorbell's sound.After warm greetings he invited the professor to his drawing room.The room was full of neatly arranged sanskrit manuscripts and books.Professor handed him the first slip and added ,"Do you know its meaning?" Desai smiled after ten seconds and said,"This is not complete.In a minute i will show you the source of the message.He walked to the rack and picked one book out.He flipped through some pages and stopped at one place.He gave the book to professor with a satisfied look.Professor was puzzled to see one more line added to shloka.  

    Desai told,"This is a problem taken out from the most famous mathematics book ever : Lilavati." Professor interrupted him,"What is the meaning?" Desai replied,"Dear eyed lilavati ,what will be the 135 multiplied by 12.The answer is 1620". Professor nodded in agreement. Desai continued,"Of course crore times of 1620 is another thing.Mr gautam you are sitting on a pile of 1620 crore." Professor said,"Not yet". He handed him the remaining two pieces.Desai gave up after a long struggle of twenty minutes.Professor thanked him and returned to his house.

item.title: Mystery of Will part 4
item.dc:creator: sanjeevnjha
item.content:encoded: It was 11'0 clock in the night when gautam returned to his house.He placed the pieces on table and started working on them.After 2 hour of unsuccessful attempts he gave in and slept on the beanbag.   He woke up at the nine o clock in the morning.He asked his servant for a cup of coffee.Gautam was now sure that he needed help to crack the remaining two pieces.His mind echoed only one name :Neelam.She was a co teacher in the same college and professor Gautam always admired her beauty and brains.He picked up the phone and dialled Neelam's number. ---Hello! Neelam!! ---Gautam!So nice to hear from you. --- What are you doing? ---I am going to Landmark.I have to buy some books for my mom. -- Is yourmom,ok? -- Apart from wheel chair,Yes.Though some times she misses her job as librarian. --Drop everything and come to my house. -- Is it urgent? -- Yes. --Ok.I will reach there in one hour. Gautam cut the call and went for shower. At 12'o clock Neelam reached the Gautam's house.Guatam invited her inside.Gautam briefed her about the visit of kumar and 3 paper slips.He handed her the first slip. "Are you solving Lilavati these days.Any way answer is 1620",Neelam Said. Gautam cursed himself for not asking her in first place.He handed her the remaining two pieces. After a careful study of 10 minutes,Neelam said, " This is an example of sequential puzzle.First question was just to arouse your interest.3rd piece is useless without the answer of second.We have to find the answer of second piece and that will serve as key for solving the third one." Gautam asked,"Can you crack the second one." Neelam said,"Whats your opinion?" Gautam replied,"I think this slip talks about some kind of message system." --True.It talks about a telegraph system.In telegraph systems,messages travel from one pole to another. --Ok.So the word "ends" means poles in cryptic notation. --Probably. --But what about : "ends in suspense." --Cant figure that out.Not yet. --- How the word "suspense" is related to the telegraph system. --Yes. --What about this.J C Bose demonstrated Telegraph in calcutta town hall two years before Marconi.This was suspense for long time. -- Gaps have started to fill in.You scored one over me. Gautam felt true happiness.Finally his brains proved superior to Neelam's.But he kept the straight face.Probably he did not wanted to hurt Neelam's feelings.He said,"How about a cup of coffee to celebrate victory?" Neelam replied with the closed eyes,"Not bad." Gautam went inside the kitchen to make the coffee.He came back after 10 minutes holding the coffee mugs.He was surprised to see Neelam still sitting with closed eyes and lost in thoughts.

item.title: Mystery of Will part 5
item.dc:creator: sanjeevnjha
item.content:encoded: Gautam said,"Dont like to loose." Neelam replied with a smile,"Dont want to break your heart.But calcutta town hall is not the answer.Check this fact that Bose demonstrated it over a distance of just 25 meters." -- So what? --How will you determine the source and destination over a distance over 25 meters? Bose could have been standing anywhere in the room. --We can check old newspaper records. --Idiot!  Will someone report that where he was standing relative to the room.   --Old photographs. -- Stop dreaming.It was just a prototype.The slip mentions a established telegraph system with source and destination. --Should we search all the telegraph lines over google? --Try it.But i dont think that will help.The key to secong slip is "ends in suspense". --But both the ends of the telegraph line will be well known.Rite? --Of course. Even one hour of brain storming failed to tie the loose ends.Finally they left the puzzle and started talking about their campus life.At 4'o clock Neelam left for her house. For next five days both regularly discussed the problem but nothing came out.One day Sitting in his house,Gautam was worried about Neelam.He knew that she lived a hard life.Apart from classes she had to take care ofher mother also.He picked the phone and dialled her number. --Hi!Neelam! --Thanks for call.No luck with the puzzle.I tried to make the list of cities which might sound as suspense or anything related to suspense.But no luck. --Will you take my advice. -- Sure -- Leave this and go out.Sometimes its better to leave the problem alone.It helps in the long run.Ok. -- Ok.I will go out.I need to buy some books for my mother. --Yeah.You talked about that one week back.Go and finish that. -- Okie.Bye. -- Bye. Its always easy to give advice.For Gautam it was impossible to take his mind off the problem.He started to solve this in mind.Gautam was lost in the problem.After 2 hours,his cellphone flashed.He opened the message: "Comes soon.Wedding is about to start". Gautam cursed himself.He completely forgot his friend's wedding.He dressed up quickly and left for the wedding place. Even after 80 minutes of driving,he has covered only half way.It was a terrible traffic jam.Gautam switched the AC to maximum and tried to relax. Suddenly his phone started ringing.It was Neelam on the other side.He picked up the call. --Hi Neelam! --Listen! I know the answer to second piece. --R u sure? -- 100% Baby.Thanks to you. --Why me? --You gave the advice to go out. -- What going out has to do with this? --Everything -- Means --Today i came to buy the books for my mother.When i saw the cover of one book,it came to me in a flash.This was never about JC Bose,Marconi or Telegraph. --Explain. --Cant yaar.Its too crowded and difficult to hear anything.Meet me at my house in one hour. Gautam always hated Neelam for showing off.He knew that she wanted to reveal the secret like Sherlock holmes in her house.He turned his car towards the Neelam's house.   At the other peaceful end inside the bookstore,Neelam was smiling.She loved to hold the secrets.Gautam was right about her!

item.title: Who Killed Rajeshwari
item.dc:creator: sanjeevnjha
item.content:encoded: With the acquittal of Nagmani, the mystery of Rajeshwari ‘s death deepens. The District and Sessions Judge, Patna, held that the evidence against her husband Nagmani was "circumstantial" and that "it was more probable that she moved out of Nagmani’s quarters alive as she had become desperate. The complicity of the accused in the murder even outside the house has not been esta-blished and his conduct cannot be said to be inconsistent with his innocence in the background of her previous disappearances." You are lucky, you know, to have Nagaswamy as your husband ," a retired judge attending Nagmani's marriage told the pretty bride. The bride, Rajeshwari, replied: "Not me ,It is he who's lucky to have me as wife". Nagmani was within hearing distance. He took this as an affront. Were the newly-weds set on a collision course right there in the marriage mandap? The events that followed open the curtain into a tragic case involving two highly educated families from Madras whose domestic in-fights and squabbles over matters like dowry and custody of children ended in the brutal death of Nagmani's wife. The case was peculiar—it had no approver, no eyewitnesses and no accomplices. The evidence was "circumstantial". Nagmani was the only one to be charged with the murder. Two others, Dr R. K. Prasad, Civil Assistant Surgeon in Patna, and Dalchand Kahar a peon staying in the compound of the residence of the Nagmani’s had been arrested and later discharged by the court. Although the murder took place on the night of March 2, 1973, Nagmani was arrested five months later. He was at the time Commissioner of the Tirhut Division and Vice-Chancellor of Bihar University. Big Draw With Women Nagmani was at the top of his career and had acquired a reputation for hard work, discipline and administrative ability. A man of great charm, he, was known for his good looks, gentleness and cool temper, He was a big draw with the women in his community and a most eligible bachelor at the time or his marriage—an " arranged " affair. He began his career as a lecturer in Presidency College, Madras, and later entered the Indian administrative service. A women less gifted than Rajeshwari and less stubborn would have made attempts to save her marriage .Not Rajeshwari - she was willing to break rather than bend. People who were acquainted with Rajeshwari feel that she might have escaped her tragic fate if only she had tempered her pride, been less impetuous and exercised some self-restraint. Rajeshwari had a brilliant academic career. She did her MA, and MSc in Mathematics before going in for Law.She was fluent in Tamil, English and French .She is known to have kept a day-to-day account in French of the goings on in her household . Rajeshwari's father, Dr Sabesan, was a reputed medical practitioner in Madras .Being the youngest of three daughters, she was his favourite.Dr Sabesan's greatest ambition was to see that his favourite daughter got a husband worthy of her And Nagmani an IAS man, with a brilliant career before him, was the best choice he could think of. The Case Of The Prosecution Let us examine the case which has been unfolded in the Court of Mr S. N P Sinha, District and Sessions Judge, Patna . Rajeshwari disappeared from the residence of her husband on Hardinge Road, Patna, on the night of March 2, 1973 .The following day, the body of an "unidentified woman" was found lying naked, off the national highway in Didupur village (Barth), 45 kilometres from Patna .A well-meaning villager covered it with a towel. The body was removed to the local civil hospital where at. S. P. Sinha, Civil Assistant Surgeon, did the autopsy. The police had earlier reported that the peon Dalchand had told them that Nagmani held Rajeshwari's head, Dalchand caught her feet while Dr Prasad injected her with poison. The police case was that an attempt was made to throw the body into the Ganga. It being Shivaratri, there was a big crowd. The body was therefore abandoned on the road-side. Later on, however, the peon denied any knowledge of the murder. The morning after the murder, Nagmani told everybody that his wife had fled. On March 3, Nagmani's son Sukumar learnt from Dalchand's 11-year-old daughter about the fate of his mother. He went to a family friend named Mr Laghate, borrowed Rs 50 from him, and went to Calcutta to meet his aunt, Mrs Vaidyanathan. Sukumar's uncle, Mr Vaidyanathan, then wrote to the Chief Secretary of Bihar, Mr Menon (who had been his classmate) to inquire into the whereabouts of Rajeshwari .There was no reply. CBI Inquiry Ordered Meanwhile, Mrs Vaidyanathan wrote to the Police Superintendent of Patna, and Sukumar sent a petition to the Chief Secretary calling for a search of his missing mother. All these did not produce any results. Vaidyanathan trunk called Menon from Calcutta. Only after that was an inquiry ordered by the State Government. During a search of Nagmani's house, the police found the petition that Sukunar had written to the Chief Secretary. This caused many to believe that "high officials were favouring Nagmani". Mrs Vaidyanathan contacted the higher-ups in Delhi and a CBI inquiry was ordered. Nagmani wrote to the Home Secretary saying that his wife had disappeared from his house for the third time during their wedded life. (The first time was in June 1959 and the second in March 1964.) . Bone Of Contention How did things come to such a pass? Soon after the marriage, it appears, dowry became a major bone of contention. Nagmani's father (a retired employee of the Audit and Accounts Department of Tamil Nadu Government) was anxious that Rajeshwari’s savings certificates of Rs 10,000 should be transferred to his son's name. Tension over the savings certificates mounted. Rajeshwari's old parents, increasingly anxious about their daughter's future, transferred the house where they lived in Gopalapuram to her name. Nagmani resented this. He retaliated by forcing Rajeshwari to ask for rent from her parents since they were no longer owners of the house. The parents, it appears, paid the rent as long as they lived. When they died, she was pressed to sell the louse. Key Witnesses Nagmani's 19-year-old son, N. Sukumar said in his evidence that he did not trust his other when he told him; "Sukumar, do you know your mother has again decamped? Did he say anything to you against me?"   Sukumar gave the following reasons for not believing his father. "Relations between my father and mother were strained... my mother could not have left without telling me there was no clash between father and mother on the previous day .. my mother had told me that she was determined to change the impression of my father that she had left on earlier occasions like an unfaithful wife .." Was Father Cruel ? Sukumar added that his father was "not only cruel to my mother, but had no mercy for the lives of animals." He gave an instance. A dog had strayed into their courtyard. Nagmani had all the doors of the courtyard closed. Then he and three or four peons with sticks and flaming "mashals" (torches) in their hands chased the dog. They started beating the dog till it fell dead. Nagmani had the carcass thrown away by the peons. Sukumar further stated that his mother used to get money from Nagmani for domestic expenses only "after a lot of haggling". Dr Annapurna, elder sister of Rajeshwari and Deputy Chief Medical Officer of Bharat Heavy Electricals, stated that their father, Dr Sabesan, died of shock on learning that Nagmani had snatched away both sons of Rajeshwari from her custody in Madras some time in 1968. She claimed, in her examination-in-chief, that Nagmani was "very indifferent and negligent to his wife from the very day of his marriage . He never cared for his wife" . On their wedding day, after the reception was over, Rajeshwari came to her crying and said that Nagmani bad abused their family saying that "we did not know how to receive an IAS bridegroom and an IAS bridegroom's party". Once when Nagmani had to leave for Patna, he entrusted the custody of his son, Sukumar, to his mother at the railway station .Rajeshwari tried to take away her son from her mother-in-law but did not succeed. Rajeshwari then filed a suit in the Madras High Court praying for the custody of her son and the Court granted her prayer. DEFENCE COUNSEL NAGESHWAR PRASAD He suggested that Raleshwari was likely to have become a victim of robbers who snatched her ornaments and the costly sari she was wearing. Dr Annapurna further deposed that Nagmani carried on his affairs with other women and did not behave well with his wife even after a compromise in 1971. Mr E G, Vaidyanathan, prime prosecution witness, told the court that Rajeshwari was living with her husband "like a bird in a cage". Nagmani went on a trip to the United Kingdom and on his return, towards the end of 1964, his wife found two photographs of a foreign lady with some "remarks on them". Later she showed these photographs to Vaidyanathan .When the prosecution exhibited copies of the photographs, the defence counsel said: "Legally it cannot go as evidence" . Defence Counsel : Were the proofs which were in possession of Mrs Rajeshwari disclosed to anybody? Witness : The proof was that her son, Sukumar, had been an eyewitness As far as I know, she did not disclose it to anybody . Defence : Still you took her to a detective agency in Calcutta for collection of proof? Witness: To secure concrete proof Defence: The detective's fee was fixed at Rs 4,000 Who was to pay it? Witness : It was fixed at Rs 4,000 and Mrs Rajeshwari was to pay. Defence: Why was the discovery through the detective agency given up? Witness : Before the agency could act, she disappeared. When he deposed for the first time, Assistant Civil Surgeon of Barh, Dr J. P Sinha who did the post-mortem, told the Sessions Court that the death was "unnatural and sudden" .He ruled out strangulation as a cause. He said one of the top incisor teeth was found broken. There was also an injury on the forehead .To him, both these injuries appeared to be before her death. The doctor said that the fluid in the stomach could be of some drink but there was an "unnatural smell' in it. When asked by the court to spell out "unnatural smell", the doctor said, "the smell that generally comes out after the stomach is opened was not there." . The Summing-Up The prosecution counsel, Mr P. S. Mishra, argued that from the facts and circumstances that had emerged during the trial, Rajeshwari’s death by cyanide poisoning could not be ruled out .The counsel read out from books written by eminent toxicologists to show that cyanide administered in a small quantity could prove fatal .Quoting from them, the counsel pointed out that there were four prominent symptoms of death from such poisoning—redness of the mucosa, unnatural smell when stomach is opened during autopsy, empty bladder and presence of blood in the heart. The post-mortem report of the then Assistant Surgeon of Barh who did the autopsy on Rajeshwari’s body mentioned all these facts in his report, he said. "'The next phase would be to establish a strong enough motive for the crime," the prosecution counsel argued. Four aspects, he said, had to be considered—that the accused never got reconciled to the idea that he had obligations towards his wife or that a wife has to be treated with discretion and affection; secondly, (accused) had been ill-treating her and wished that she should leave him free; thirdly, he entertained a feeling that Rajeshwari was proving a burden and a hindrance m his freelancing in sex; and, fourthly, he had a lust for the personal properties, both movable and immovable, of Rajeshwari .As the latter was not willing to part with them, the accused maintained a covert grudge against her." The Case Of The Defence Defence Counsel Nageshwar Prasad maintained that the official residence of Nagmani in western Patna was flanked by houses which were under occupation of two top police officials and a State Minister. Those houses were guarded round the clock. Any motor car coming in or going out of Nagmani's residence would have at once attracted the attention of the guards on duty. On the other hand, it was possible for Rajeshwari "to quietly slip out of the house without drawing anybody's attention." There was no positive or direct evidence of Rajeshwari's body being carried away in a motor car and of its having been abandoned at considerable distance from Patna. He said the facts of the case "were clear pointers to the fact that Rajeshwari who was a woman of a volatile temperament and of a sentimental type left the house of her own accord". Mr Prasad read out from a letter dated January 7, 1973, written by Rajeshwari to her sister Dr Annapurna in which she had said, "Most probably I will have to run away for the third time". The facts of the case would go to show that her brother-in-law, Vaidyanathan, had arranged a meeting with. the husband of the woman with whom Nagmani allegedly had clandestine relations at Dhanbad—the meeting was scheduled to take place either on March 3 or 4, 1973. It was also on record that Rajeshwari was informed about the meeting and "it is quite possible that Rajeshwari left the house to participate in that meeting the outcome of Which virtually concerned her", Mr Prasad said. He said that information about this Dhanbad meeting was conveyed by Mrs Vaidyanathan (elder sister of Rajeshwari) in a letter which was not sent to Rajeshwari direct but through their friend, Mrs S. K. Laghate. Mr Prasad added: "Though the prosecution has produced so many letters in this case, this letter has been withheld. This letter might possibly have given an inkling as to what arrangements they had made for Rajeshwari to go to Dhanbad or why she left the house." How Reliable Is The Evidence? Mr Prasad said "The whole of the present case is founded on two important things —firstly, letters written by Rajeshwari to her parents and sisters and Sukumar's evidence" .   About Rajeshwari, he said: "From her own letters and from affidavits filed by her in courts it would appear that she was prone to take recourse to falsehoods, she was suspicious, she was given to making false accusation on flimsy, flippant and frivolous grounds not only against her husband, but also against her own children and other relations." Mr Prasad continued "This is the type of woman we are confronted with and it is to be considered whether reliance could be placed on the letters, diaries, etc, written and maintained by her and on the basis of which the prosecution has built up its case". About Sukumar, Mr Prasad said that he "was not a trustworthy witness". "Like his mother he is also prone to take recourse to falsehoods, lie is in the habit of exaggerating things and facts, given to flights of imagination, and has developed a love for books on sex from a very early age. "Over and above, the boy came to depose while under the guardianship of Vaidyanathan who is definitely hostile to Nagmani " . Death Due To Shock, Not Poisoning The defence counsel argued that the theory advanced by the prosecution that Mrs Rajeshwari had died of "cyanide" poisoning must be rejected. He read out relevant portions of the jurisprudence and explained that the symptoms of the dead body of Rajeshwari did not tally with the symptoms narrated in detail in Modes Medical Jurisprudence. He asserted that Rajeshwari’s death was due to sudden shock and fright. He said that the post-mortem report revealed that the bowel and bladders were found empty. Nobody exactly knew in what manner Rajeshwari died. He said that Rajeshwari was wearing costly ornaments when she was supposed to have left her husband's house and she was likely to have become a victim of robbers. All this could have caused sudden shock and. fright. Rajeshwari collapsed and the robbers took away even the costly sari which she was wearing then. Acquitting the accused, the judge, Mr Sinha, observed- "The guilt of the accused has to be adjudged not by the fact that a vast number of people believed him to be guilty but whether his guilt has been established by the evidence on record."

item.title: Brahman,Thief and Ogre : A tale from Panchatantra
item.dc:creator: sanjeevnjha
item.content:encoded: Once a certain poor brahman received a present of a pair of cows, which had been brought up from young calves by feeding with ghee,oil, salt, grass, and (other) wholesome foods, so that they were very fat. And a certain thief saw them, and he thought as follows: "This very day I shall steal them." So he started out in the early evening, and as he went along some unknown person touched him on the shoulder. Whereupon he asked in alarm: "Who are you?" And he spoke truthfully: "I am a night-roaming brahman ogre.You also tell me who you are." Said he: am a thief".   And when the other asked again: -Where are you going?" he said: "I intend to steal a pair of cows from a certain brahman But where are you going?" Then being reassured by this information the brahman ogre also said: "I too have started out to seize that same brahman."   Then they went thither both together and stayed at one side, waiting for the proper time. And when the brahman had gone to sleep the brahman ogre was creeping up to seize him first; when the thief said to him: "This is not the right way. After I have stolen his two cows, then you may seize him." Said the other: "That too would be wrong. Perchance the noise of the cows might wake him, and then I should have come in vain."   The thief said: "If when you seize him he gets up and makes an outcry,then everybody will be roused; and then I cannot steal his two cows. So I will steal the cows first, and afterwards you may eat the brahman."   As they were thus disputing with one another they got angry, and with their rivalry they straightway woke up the brahman. Thereupon the thief said: "Brahman,this brahman ogre wants to seize you." But the brahman ogre said: "This thief wants to steal your two cows." Hearing this the brahman got up and being put on his guard saved himself from the ogre by reciting the mantra  of his sect's deity, and saved his two cows from the thief by brandishing his cudgel. So both the thief and the ogre ran away.   Therefore I say: "Even enemies may be useful when they fall out with each other. The thief saved (the brahman's) life, while the ogre (saved) his two cows."

wp:comment.wp:comment_content: Short and sweet with a moral .. and a colorful picture too!!

item.title: Miss prem mathur first women commercial pilot of india
item.dc:creator: sanjeevnjha
item.content:encoded: The thirties, that glorious decade when Amy Johnson and Amelia Earhart were blazing trails across the skies, saw Indian pioneer women flyers taking to the air. And in 1940 Bombay-born Miss Urmila Parekh and Miss Rodaben Tata won their wings. Quietly and unobtrusively, they took to the air and opened up new horizons to the many eager women who followed. First To Hit Headlines Shy of publicity, it was not until after independence that India's women pilots really hit the headlines. First to do so was Miss Prem Mathur. Against well-meant but pessimistic advice, she entered the National Air Race in 1949. Her rivals were flying instructors, ex-Air Force personnel and an experienced Army general who had won the Willingdon Trophy twice.She considered this as good an opportunity as any and no one was more surprised than she when she came in first in a spectacular finish and with the added distinction of having consumed the least fuel. Next to win a prize was a princess, Kunwarani Kusum B. Singh, who carried off. a special trophy and a prize of £100 in 1950. The story of Prem Mathur's flying career is a saga in itself.One evening she went up for a joy-ride in a battered disposals plane which was still flying-fit.Her intelligent reactions to the many interesting gadgets in the cockpit drew the pilot's attention, and it was not long before Miss Mathur was herself at the controls as a trainee. Snatched Time Off Still a college student, she concentrated on studies in the morning and afternoon but snatched time off in the evenings to pursue her fascinating new hobby. In 1948, she received her "A" licence. It was her subséquent success in the National Air Race which first put ideas into her head-if she could beat men in an air race, what was to prevent her obtaining a commercial "B" licence to qualify as a professional civil pilot? With that grit and nerve which has characterised her entire career (friendly advice about leaving flying to men having abated some what after her success in the National Air Race) she got permission to continue her technical training at her home town of Allahabad after completing her flying hours at Lucknow. No Special Privileges Mainly to stress that she wanted no special privileges on the grounds of sex, she lived in a bleak but, tidy cubicle in the men's bar-racks at the Aviation Training Centre. Having passed her technical tests, she returned to Lucknow to complete her flying training and in 1951 had the satisfaction of obtaining her coveted commercial "B" licence. The next stage-actual flying in twin-engine planes for the final endorsement of her licence-proved a little tougher than she had imagined and for the first time opened her eyes to what she was up against.   Actual apprentice training is available only with airlines, and no women pilots have been employed in airlines anywhere in the world. Test Pilot's Support Nothing daunted, Miss Mathur .She won the support and encouragement of one of India's leading jet test pilots, who was willing to vouch for her ability, and with a little patient pleading one of India's leading airlines agreed to take her on temporarily and without remuneration as a co-pilot on their Hyderabad-Bangalore-Bombay route. Trim and attractive in her flying kit, she was meticulous about carrying out all normal duties, including climbing on trie wings to "take the dips " and taking her turn at the controls for take offs and even night landings. Her captains were always confident of her skill, and the passengers intrigued, amused, Impressed but never frightened to see her at the controls. After seven months of regular duty, Miss Mathur had to give up her temporary flying job and now sits at the desk of her brother's travel agency in New Delhi, dreaming of the day when she will be flying the commercial planes for which she now books passengers.

item.title: Vijaya Lakshmi Pandit Down the Memory Lane
item.dc:creator: sanjeevnjha
item.content:encoded: IN THE ORNATE LOBBY of San Francisco's Palace Hotel in 1945, during the world conference that brought the United Nations to birth, a slender dark-skinned woman with silvery hair and gleaming white teeth gathered her rich scarlet sari around her and smiled as a French diplomat bent over her dusky hand. He complimented her on her striking appearance, and as a woman she was flattered. But her smile froze at his choice of words: "Your native dress, Madame Pandit," he said, "is magnificent." "For my part," she replied coldly, with a pointed look at his cutaway jacket and striped trousers, "I have always found the European native dress curiously dull." That incident, trivial in itself, nevertheless highlighted the extreme sensitivity which always has characterised the woman who now becomes the first of her sex to preside over a General Assembly of the United Nations. Mrs. Vijaya Lakshmi Pandit, sister of India's Premier, Jawaharlal Nehru, lifelong friend of Gandhi, a firebrand, and, though she affects to resent the role, one of the world's outstanding feminists. Perhaps significantly, her apparent anxiety not to be regarded as a feminist shone through the very first statement she made on picking up the gavel at United Nations Headquarters, as Canada's Lester Pearson laid it down. "All my political training,"said the woman who has been India's Ambassador both to Moscow and to Washington," has taught me to look upon myself as an individual, and not essentially as a woman. I don't care for this emphasis on women." Born To Wealth And yet, only a moment before, in formally accepting the Assembly presidency, she had characterised her appointment as "a recognition of the part that women have played in furthering the aims and purposes of this great organisation."It is only too clear that deep in her womanhood as well as in her nationality are the roots which have made Madame Pandit what she is. Born to wealth, she has battled throughout her life against poverty.Educated by private tutor sand English governesses, she has battled against illiteracy and under privilege. Born in a social set which had everything to gain from Britain's presence in India, she battled against the British Raj for many years. Now that there is no longer any British Raj to fight against in her own land, she emerges as the self-appointed champion of Africans and of Asians in non-Indian lands, against what she still calls "imperialism."It has been said of her, "she does not know that Kipling is dead." Whatever her personal political coloration, Madame Pandit brings to her task at the United Nations many years of solid diplomatic and U.N. experience. She headed the Indian delegation to U.N.'s first General Assembly, back in 1946, before India had received her full independence ,and has been in the thick of U.N. affairs ever since. They have, in the main, been for her more placid years than those she spent on Indian picket lines, in rabble rousing speech making, in underground Civil disobedience activities designed to kick the underpinnings from under British authority in the sub Continent. Those were the years that three times saw her spend brief spells in British prisons, only to emerge more determined than before to stand in the forefront of the fight. At 53 she is softly spoken with a marked B.B.C. accent ,a grandmother of four, every inch the aristocrat and the possessor, when she cares to use it, of as razor edged a tongue as is heard in the halls of diplomacy. Vijaya Lakshmi Pandit was the daughter of an Indian lawyer and rebel, Motilal Nehru, a millionaire who devoted much of his personal fortune to financing Gandhi and those who followed after him.At 21-late for an Indian girl at that time-she married R. S. Pandit, a scholar, lawyer and a famous Sanskrit poet. He too was a supporter of the Home Rule movement. He died 10 years ago. Talented Linguist Their three daughters were all educated at Wellesley College, one of America's most exclusive academies for the daughters of the rich and privileged. All are now in India, married to officials of the new Government. Mrs Pandit herself went to one of Switzerland's most fashionable finishing schools ,and is a talented linguist. Her father often entertained Gandhi in their luxurious summer home in the cool hills above Delhi, and it was at the Mahatma's bony knee that the girl "learned the ropes" as an implacable foe of all things British. Her first taste of gaol came in 1932, when she was sentenced to a year's imprisonment, thus joining the ranks of that growing rebel elite who prided themselves on having been "a guest of his Majesty's Government."Her last prison term came as late as 1943, when she received a nine-month sentence. In November of 1944 she went on a world tour, which she paid for herself, as a self appointed "beater-up" of world opinion in favour of "throwing the British out of India."She spoke throughout the United States, which she always regarded as India's chief hope in bringing pressure to bear upon the authorities in London. Heavy though the reliance which she placed upon American opinion has been, she has by no means always seen eye to eye with American policy. She has, in particular, stoutly opposed Washington's thinking on the subject of Red China, though she has few illusions about that Asian nation's "democracy." Her trip into China at the head of an Indian cultural mission impressed her with the apparent durability of the Peiping regime. But she said bluntly that what she had observed there did not fit in with her conception of democracy. Jai Hind She still greets friends and foes alike with the rallying cry of the Indian revolutionaries: "Jai hind!" ("long live India"). Friend of the underdog she may be, but Vijaya Lakshmi Pandit is not fond of unnecessary austerity in her own life. Her jewels are such as to draw admiring comment from the experts. Only the choicest silks go into her saris. She is a connoisseur of good food, and cooks well especially the spicy dishes of her native land. In recent years she has shown a tendency to shun the bright colours that she once favoured for her silken gowns, preferring now a gentle lavender or a soft dove grey, a simple print, sometimes even black.She claims that there are few things she does not like. Among these, she lists cats. But even to cats she pays a debt of gratitude. "I tolerated them while I was in prison," she says. "They were my friends then.They killed the rats."

item.title: Nizam of Hyderabad A RULER WITH STACKS OF GOLD AND JEWELS
item.dc:creator: sanjeevnjha
item.content:encoded: World's richest man, the Nizam of Hyderabad came into the news when the Dominion of India recently called on him to make up his mind without delay whether to bring his State into the Dominion or keep it independent. He probably finds it hard to decide. The Dominion of India is predominantly Hindu, and more than 15,000,000 of the Nizam's 20,000,000 subjects are Hindus: but the Nizam is a Moslem.In India, Hindu Princes, known as Maharajas, and Moslem Princes known as Nawabs have the additional title "His Highness" but the Nizam shares his title with no other ruler. Ever since the Indian Mutiny of 1857, when Hyderabad stood by Britain, Hyderabad's ruler has held by tradition the title Faithful Ally of the British Government. In 1918, King George V made this traditional title His Exalted Highness. This was the Nizam's reward for a World War 1 manifesto in which he appealed to the Moslems of India to support Britain even though Turkey, a Moslem Power,was on the German side. The Nizam's real name is Sir Mir Osman Ali Khan Bahadur. That's a short name in India-the Maharaja of Patiala, for instance is known as Lieutenant-General His Highness Farzand-i-Khas-i-Daudat-i-Inglishia Shri Maharajadhiraj Mohinder Bahadur. The Nizam claims descent from the Caliph Abu Bakr, Moham-med's successor as the spiritual and temporal head of Islam. A more recent ancestor, Nizam Ul Mulk Asaf Jah, founded Hyderabad during the Mogul Empire's disintegration 200 years ago. In 1931 the Nizam gained added distinction in the Islamic world when his heir, Prince Azam Jah,and his second son married the daughter and niece respectively of the ex-Caliph of Islam, ex-Sultan Abdul Mejid of Turkey. His Exalted Highness is a slight,shy, frugal cultured man who rules a State the size of Victoria on the windswept tablelands of the Deccan, in southern India.He has power of life and death over his subjects. His rule is a benevolent despotism.He has his own army, customs service, university (with 10 colleges), stamps, railways, and an airline. His paper currency ls the only one circulating in India besides the British rupee notes.He claims none ever goes hungry in Hyderabad. He generally needs a haircut, his long moustache is perpetually shaggy. He wears European suits on special occasions, but more often homespun clothes, old leather shoes, a well-worn fez, and carries a walking stick mended with an Iron ring. He is the seventh Nizam, but nothing like his father, who was almost a Hollywood version of what an Indian Prince should be. The old boy rode around on gold draped elephants and in Rolls Royces, went tiger-shooting with an enormous retinue, wore his jewels. Those jewels he could not wear he sewed into bags and used them as door stops in his palaces.He was also a great tosspot and after a wild night liked to throw coins in the air and shoot at them with a revolver. For many years he had many wives, but no sons. Then he fell for a Hindu dancing girl who eventually produced Osman, the present Nizam. The old boy recognised the baby as his son and heir, but later, when a legal wife produced two sons, he began to hate his first-born son. Osman grew up disliking his father and adoring his mother. When his father died he put his mother in a palace and visited her daily. He nearly went mad when she died, and every afternoon since has visited her now empty palace and her tomb. On the death of his father, the present Nizam began to economise .He closed the famous Falaknuma Palace in Hyderabad City, the State capital, and moved into the suburbs, and for years has lived in a small house among a collection of small houses in a green compound surrounded by a high wall. He shares a verandah with his pet goat. For decades now he has led a quiet, completely unostentatious existence. He is no miser, but his tastes and needs are so simple that he spends practically nothing on himself. The State pays almost all his expenses. Local merchants supply him free with clothes, toilet articles, cigarettes. The royal elephants have not been used since his coronation durbar in 1911. When he goes out he generally uses a prehistoric Ford, though he owns a Humber. He regards display, parades, trappings as distasteful. He dislikes the cinema and won't read novels. He has never been in aeroplane and doesn't intend to get into one. Like all his ancestors he has never been outside India. No one knows how much His Exalted Highness is worth. It's even said he doesn't know exactly himself. Estimates put his annual in-come at more than £5,000,000, his fold at between £30,000,000 and£50,000,000, and his jewellery at between £250,000,000 and £300,000,000. His total personal expenditure averages £1/4/4 a week. His civil list, paid by State funds, is £500,000. His income from Crown lands - the Nizam's private estate covers one tenth of Hyderabad's 83,000 square miles and is inhabited by 1,500,000 people - is worth about £2,500,000. In addition, gifts to the Nizam’s are worth millions a year. When the Nizam receives one of his subjects, that subject must present him with a gold coin worth £10,plus four silver rupees worth 7/6. Some of his nobles regard the presentation of one gold coin at a time as degrading. They some times bring as many as 30 or 40 to an audience.Four times a year he entertains thousands of guests at lavish banquets, and each guest personally hands to the Nizam a gold coin and four rupees. The Nizam is said to have saved about £170,000,000 during his 36 years' reign. His jewels, which he seldom looks at, would pay a National Debt. One story says he could lay a pavement of pearls from Oxford Circus to Charing Cross, a distance of half a mlle. YEARS back the Nizam gave orders for his pearls to be taken from their sacks,washed in a special solution which would preserve their lustre, and graded.Servants took 3 days to spreadthe pearls on the flat roofs of the dozen buildings in his compound,but after the pearls had been treated he decided it would take too long to grade them and countermanded his order.His jewel collection Includes the Jacobs diamond - used by his father as a paper weight-a set of three egg-size diamonds, and a magnificent set of emeralds worth millions. An expert who once repaired some of the Nizam's Jewellery saw only part of the collection. He estimated that part to be worth about £50,000,000.The Nizam has no treasure house, no strong room. He keeps most of his wealth in two main buildings within his suburban compound.Gold, in coins, bars and keg shaped blocks, overflows from rooms into a garage. There's so much of it that the Nizam forgets where he puts it. Once, behind some old tapestries, he was surprised to find boxes filled with gold coin. Another time a truck brought a load of gold bar. There was no place to store it, so the Nizam ordered a sentry to be posted. That was 20 years ago. Today the rotting truck is still in the same place, covered with weeds, and a small tree has grown up through the chassis. The gold is still there and a sentry still watches it. In one corner of the compound is a cart filled with sacks of silver rupees. The sacks are rotting and some tarnished coins have fallen on the ground. The Nizam could see the cart from his verandah, but he never looks at it. His Exalted Highness may sound like an almost certifiable eccentric, but at 61, he is an extremely intelligent alert, astute old character.He works harder than any of his subjects. He knows everything there is to know, even the latest scandal, in Hyderabad. HE gets up at dawn, drinks a cup of coffee, works until 9 a.m. Then he has breakfast of tea and biscuits and watches his pet goat being fed. During the morning he sits on his verandah steps and conducts affairs of State. His ministers,secretaries, and visitors stand in a respectful semicircle.Late in the afternoon, after more work, he visits his - mother's palace and tomb. Police stop all traffic. His subjects stand silent as he passes in his old Ford. He often works late at night after a simple supper. That work includes State business, writing a column, free for a Hyderabad City newspaper, reading Persian classics and the Koran, and writing poetry.The Nizam is a lonely, but not sad man. He loves conversation and laughter, and enjoys the gossip of his ministers and courtiers .He even collects jokes and stories about himself. Once an American corresponddent asked him the exact number of his children (he is reputed to have a harem of 200). His Exalted Highness smiled and said: "The census returns are not up to date, but I would be glad to provide you with this week's figures."

wp:comment.wp:comment_content: Hi Sanjeev Very nice article on Hydrabad Nizams. Thanks for all the interesting info. Cheers Nag

item.title: Satyajit Ray FROM ADMAN TO FILM DIRECTOR
item.dc:creator: sanjeevnjha
item.content:encoded: INDIAN film director Satyajit Ray is almost a one-man production team.He produces and directs the films, is often his own cameraman.He writes the scenarios, original screenplays, composes the background music, does sketches for credit titles, has designed sets and costumes, even advertising posters for his films.     The only thing he hasn't done is act. He hasn't the inclination, but he has all the attributes of a film star: height (6ft. 4hr.), good looks, dark compelling eyes, long slender hands, low voiced eloquence.He is also very elegant.He is India's and one of the world's top directors, and some of the 15 feature films he has made in the past 13 years have been shown at the festivals. But before he made his first film, "Pather Panchali," when he was art director of an advertising agency in Calcutta, he had difficulty raising finance to make the film.He sold his books, his Records. He also sold his wife's jewellery.   Today his wife is still helping him. "She's my hardest critic," he said.She is very much involved in his film-making. She discusses stories and screen plays with him, "now and again" the casting, sees the rushes, the first print. Tells him if a certain part drags, that people will walkout.Ray always respects what she says. "But that does not necessarily mean I always agree with her," he smiled.   Married for 19 years, they have one son, Sandip, 14, a "Beatles and Batman fan," who also wants to direct films."He often goes on the set with me," said Ray. "Once, when he was only six, he was watching a scene being filmed and, when the actor did the wrong thing, called Out 'cut' before I said 'cut.' " Ray is making his present film to please Sandip, who said, years ago, that Ray's (films were "so grim and grown-up." .So Ray has adapted a story Sandip liked, by Ray's grandfather.It's a musical fantasy about two young village boys, a good and a bad king, and there are goblins, magic slippers .The story also has an anti war theme: a typical Ray characteristic.   He believes films are to entertain, but he also likes to make people think. "I don't want to make esoteric films. You can compromise and still be subtle," he said.   He likes to explore as many aspects of life as possible. "Psychological problems – problems between husband and wife, love, prejudices, problems between old and new, between generations ….”.   His films have run the gamut of emotions and ages. Comedy, pathos, period, modern,from peasants to upper class, from feudal days to science fiction: the subject of his next film, which will star Peter Sellers."I'm a science fiction addict," said Ray, "generally dissatisfied with science fiction films. They are made with not much imagination or depth."I believe there is a metaphysical aspect. Films need not necessarily be about machines, robots, spaceships, but more about human beings affected by spaceship landings."   This statement just about sums up the kind of films Ray wants to make. "About human beings." He wants the human face to be photographed, too. "I am meticulous about casting," he said.   When he writes roles he knows exactly what the people look like, and chooses people closest in physical appearances, even if they are non-actors. When he is directing. Ray can "cut himself off" from the bustle and hustle of a film set.He is not temperamental. "I have a tremendous lot of patience."But when he is writing he likes to be "absolutely alone, from the family particularly. "I like to go to a seaside hotel, and there I can write undisturbed for 16 or 17 hours a day. Once I was the only guest at a hotel." He started writing scenarios long before he took up actual film-making.He would read a book which had been adapted for a film, write his own scenario, then see the film to compare the one used. "I felt mine were better," he smiled.   In fact he studied filmmaking theoretically for years before attempting to make a film. At first it was just a hobby, "but I had a background for film-making," he said.   Ray's grandfather was a scholar, writer, and musician.His father, who died when Ray was two years old, was a well-known writer in Bengal.Ray grew up with a love of music and literature, both Eastern and Western.When young he was fascinated by Beethoven. Now he prefers Bach, Bartok. In composing film music he likes to mix Indian instruments with perhaps the cello, the flute. "A lot of me is West," he said. An economics graduate, Ray studied fine arts for two and a half years at Tagore University. He is also an amateur still photographer, whose work has been exhibited. "I am prouder of those than my paintings, which have not been framed or hung."   He entered the advertising world as an artist when he was 22, and within four years was the art director. He was with the agency for ten years.He was sent to England for the agency, and while there managed to increase his film viewing. "I saw about 95 films in five months."   The first film he remembers seeing was "The Thief of Bagdad," the Douglas Fairbanks version."I was only about four or five then, but I remembered it well. All the physical feats, jumping walls, sword fights, flying carpet."When he saw the film in later years it corresponded with his memories.   As he grew older he became a film fan. He would see the same film four or five or more times, taking notes in the dark, particularly to do with the technical side.He still sees films time after time.   In 1949 he met French film director Jean Renoir, who was making "The River" in India.Ray had designed a jacket for the widely read book "Pather Panchali" and spoke to Renoir about his idea for a film adaptation. "He thought it sounded interesting and said why didn't I make it." For 12 months Ray tried to sell the scenario to producers in India, but failed.It was then that he sold some of his possessions to raise money to make some footage "just to show that he was not strictly an amateur."   There was still not enough finance, but finally the Government of West Bengal put up the money."Pather Panchali" was successful in India and also received international awards.It began a trilogy, with "Aparajito" and "The World of Apu," tracing the childhood, youth, and manhood of a boy named Apu from a Bengali village. Ray said he had no intention of making the third him, "The World of Apu," but the late Jawaharlal Nehru had once told him he would like to know what became of his Apu, and advised him to write a scenario from the original book.   As well as film-making, Ray edits a children's magazine which was started by his grandfather, went out of production when his father died, and which Ray revived about six years ago.It's a monthly magazine for which he writes, illustrates, thinks up crosswords and competitions.One of his stories, published in book form, was awarded the "children book of the year" award given annually by the Government.   Ray has translated some of the nonsense poems, from "Alice in Wonderland," and also the limericks of English humorist Edward Lear. This follows the tradition of his father, who, Ray said, wrote the Bengali "Alice in Wonderland." "It can't be translated. There are lots of nonsense rhymes."   "What do I do for relaxation? I don't relax. If I do I listen to music, but never for very long. Just until I think of a story."

item.title: Story behind the bald head of persis khambatta
item.dc:creator: sanjeevnjha
item.content:encoded: If, as they say, success in show business comes only after a period of suffering and sacrifice, then the young Indian actress Persis Khambatta deserves every twinkle of her stardom.To play the alluring bald Ilia in "Star Trek — the Motion Picture" Persis had to have her head shaved once a day and to tolerate injections from a skin specialist to reduce her blemishes for close-ups. "It just wasn't as bad as it sounds," she said. But after lunch she'd have a five o'clock shadow, and that meant no more close-ups for the day.   She caught colds because she couldn't cover her head between takes as it would ruin the makeup.And the wigs Paramount ordered weren't ready for use until the former beauty queen was already growing back her lustrous black hair.   "Why did I do it?" she said. "I didn't have to do it, but I'm a person who likes adventure."   But when the day came to have her shoulder-length hair shorn-by Fred Phillips,the movie's makeup supervisor, she couldn't bear to watch. She asked some spectators, including a documentary crew filming the event, to stand in front of the mirrors until it was over.   "I didn't want to watch because I was afraid I would jump up half-way through and say, 'stop it,' so I waited. But when I saw myself, I jumped out of the chair and said, 'wow!' It was incredible. The feelings I had. If I didn't like it, I knew I would try to grow my hair back in a hurry, but it looked good.   "Then I went home, and it was like a birthday celebration.
