Everybody wanted to come to my house and see what I looked like."   Producer Gene Roddenberry, the creator of "Star Trek," and director Robert Wise gave her a personalized electric shaver.Then the excitement was over and Persis was alone for that first, strange hairless morning.   "I was reaching for a brush when I realized I'd better lock those things away," she said. "Then I jumped in the shower and there's no telling how long I was there.   "My head was so soft and the water falling on it was such a sensual feeling. It was so exciting. I love rain and walking in the rain. This was even better. I can't describe it. "I just know I'm glad I did it. My hair is growing back so fast and it's thicker and of better quality than before," she said.   "Besides. I was tired of people taking me out and saying, 'Oh, you're a beautiful woman, Miss India, model, actress.' They just wanted to show me off. This way, I found out who my real friends were. Believe it or not, the reactions I got from men were very positive."   Persis helped in that department by working to make bald beautiful. Before the clipping, she went to London to select a new wardrobe favoring high collars which framed her face.She then helped design skull-tight leather hats with jewels and, for effect, she sometimes had an artist friend paint designs on her head.   In the movie, Persis plays the hairless Ilia, a 23rd- century Soman from the planet Delta Four, assigned to the starship Enterprise as a navigator.   Persis has found two advantages in her shorn role: now that her hair is back she is unlikely to be typecast and, she says, people don't recognize her.But she has been well known in the past. At the age of 13 she became a top model in India, and she became Miss India when she was 16. She began an acting career and, after success in India, left for London and Hollywood.

wp:comment.wp:comment_content: nice to watch pictures after very very long time
I had a tee-shirt with Ilia's picture on it. She's one gorgeous lady!

item.title: Say No to Bikini on Indian Beaches
item.dc:creator: sanjeevnjha
item.content:encoded: Are those ladies drowning? No, searching for a lost Bikini.   We present to you the collection of the funniest replies regarding to the the question of wearing Bikini on Indian Beaches.Take a look.     Answers to a Foreigner's question : Should I Wear Bikini on Indian Beaches   On a Chennai beach, you could be mobbed and even assaulted, and whether it was prompted by approval or disapproval wouldn't make any difference.   Feel free if you want hundred eyes gazing at you nonstop.   In india, I simply never see anything that a sari does not reveal unless it is my wife.Remember Even a low neckline catches the eye.   Indian women get into the sea in their saree or salwars.   Bikinis will always be fine with the ogglers.   A bikini here would start a riot. I saw that in kerala boys were busy with binoculars at varkala beach drooling over the goris in bikinis.   A bikini here would start a riot.   No no. Bikinis are not bad. It is nice to watch girls wearing bikini on the beach. Topless is even better and I dont mind totally nude.   When we were in Goa there was a HUGE Russain woman topless and a gang of 5 local boys wandered past and started laughing and pointing at her....they stood there for about 5 mins and made a big deal out it as she was sorting her towel out and flobbling all over while they were very much amused   Freedom is not doing what one pleases for the sake of it, but the ability to make good, moral choices to fulfil our social duties to our fellow human beings". M K Gandhi   Protect your skin from the tropical sunshine, rather than expose it.Two words to contemplate: skin cancer.   Bikinis aren't bad ... they're really sick!!!     Why Indian Girls don’t Wear Bikini?     Indian women have sarees which are the best garment in terms of beauty and grace.Indian women don't need a bikini to look sensuous and attract pot bellied Indian males :-)   The indian male gaze is BAD and can make any woman uncomfortable if she wears anything that is figure hugging.so forget a bikini!   I have seen people ogling like hungry wolves at girls who wear mini skirts even in a metropolitan like Delhi.     Well, it’s very easy to play the blame game but the fact is Indian women have pear shaped body that’s probably not suitable for a Bikini.   Even today in relatively small towns and cities males think that girls who wear skirts or sleeveless tops are "asking for it."   Men in india start thinking that you are the 'available' type, if you wear revealing clothes.   Indian women are really amazing with well curvy body .Totally covered. They look very and nice and mysterious . They only love to undress in front of their beloved .,trust me Its true.   In real life even american women dont wear the dresses which hollywood celebrities wear... they r also conservative..and decent and weartheir decent daily   I'd rather see cute giggling indian ladies in saris than naked tourists anyday.   I spoke to a woman in a small village in Andhra Pradesh and she had based her opinion on westerners solely on what she had seen in Pondicherry: "Those half-naked westerners are all bad people".     my hubby wants me to wear bikini on goa beach,also wants me to shed it on the beach and go topless sud i do it?   He is not your husband   Beware.. He wants u to get raped..or he badly needs a Psychiatrist   Yes go for it...Even bottomless is okay   Your should wear a bikini at your own peril   My wife cavorted around ensconsed in a sarong in the sea off beach while my brother in law and me downed one beer after another to cover our distress. He whispered to me : "Have you ever before seen a hippo dance ?"   In Goa it's true many women swim in bikinis or whatever, but it's also true that busloads of guys from cities come to Goa and one of their main attractions is to see the scantily clad women on the beach. Are you okay with that? Then wear what you like.   Your wife can go on her bikini wearing and two piece expose as she pleases but may I say that you would get to worked up on he mangoes getting a lot of attentions.   pl let me know your finding's as my wife also is very much eager to go topless in goa.       Recently in Bangladesh, I spent some time in the Sunderbans. Towards the very tip of the mangroves, we happened on a small beach where some Westerners were frolicking around in the warm shallow water, wearing bikinis.A few of the (local) women on the tour started calling out "Hai Allah" before making sure that their menfolk weren't stopping to look.The men may have been saying the same thing, wistfully       Some Foreigners Experiences     I had a dip in the water with my 2 piece swimmers on plus a t-shirt and shorts and I had 4 Indian guys come to stand around where I was. I moved and 2 of the guys followed me. It was quite annoying to me quite frankly as they were invading my personal space.   I ventured into tamil nadu and my first foray onto the beach at pondicherry had me surrounded by roughly a hundred admriers (who blocked the bloody sun for about an hour!).   I didn't really see many indian women swimming. Closest was a few who removed thier outer sari and paddled in the under petticoat ( always with husband or older son in attendance).   Indian women don't usually swim. They may bathe in holy waters, which they do indeed do in their everyday garments. In Amritsar, they dip into the holy waters undressed to their panties/knickers - within a special building so that no men can see them.   I remember getting out of the water assisted by my boyfriend, who brought a towel into the water to cover me as I came out, and still there were 30+ men staring at whatever was visible.     Even a swimsuit is a big thing for an Indian girl. It is modesty. Is considered indecent to show a body in public. Only a few city bred girls wear a swim suit.And Indian village girls bathe in rivers and ponds fully clothed! They are good natural swimmers and swim fully clothes which is wearing long skirts.   India is notorious for harassment of women (particularly white women), it’s the whole colonialism and forbidden fruit thing.

wp:comment.wp:comment_content: First of all society has to change its thinking towards wearing bikini only after that girls can feel safe wearing bikini on Indian beaches.

Quite an amusing article! I loved reading it.
But yes, Indian will always be Indians.
I would certainly love to see a woman - Indian or foreign in a bikini in India but I certainly wouldn't go close to her and 'invade her personal space'.
It's a safety hazard to swim fully clothed. So i would rather compromise my "modesty" rather than compromise my life.

item.title: A newspaper story of 1931 about the life of Hyderabad Harems
item.dc:creator: sanjeevnjha
item.content:encoded: Purdah women themselves take extra ordinary precautions to observe the rules it enforces upon them.   A Mohammedan lady visiting outside her home must take every care to see that there is no chink in a blind through which she might be seen by a man. Every window must be securely closed. “I know what you think,” an Indian Woman said apologetically to an English authoress whom her husband was graciously disposed to allow her to visit, “but I can not sit here with any degree of comfort if I think someone, a servant or one of my husband's guests, might pass by. It is instinct; my mother and my mother's mother were purdah women, and it is in the blood.”     Although in Western eyes the restrictions imposed by purdah seem to be almost unendurable, the life of a high-class lady of Hyderabad, the most Eastern city in the most Eastern land, to the lady herself is by no means so terrible.   The Begum's Day      Her day does not begin until about eight  about a.m. , when the lady starts to yawn, and a slave girl will say, “Will not the Begum rise? “  And the Begum will slowly get out of bed and allow her slave to brush her teeth with powdered charcoal and wash her face and hands.   Then she will sit down upon a mat and have her hair dressed, while other slaves come in with the clothes that will complete her toilet. If she is dressed for going out the Mohammedan lady of Hyderabad will present a gorgeous picture.   She may have as many as seven piercing  in her ears, in four of which she sets small buttons of turquoises, or other jewels, and in the others great hoops of gold in which are hanging pearls, sometimes the size of a pea.   Soon the women of the household come in and they will chew betel nut until ten ten am. When breakfast,  consisting of rice and curry and sweets, arrives. . After breakfast more friends or relatives come in with the sewing women and higher servants, and everyone talks and laughs together. In the afternoon the silk merchants may send in their wares or the jewellers - their bracelets and rings and precious stones, which are brought to the zenana by women.       Then the real gossip begins. The shop women bring all the news and scandal of other zenanas, tell who is married and dead, what presents were given and so on. Then, in the evening, the husband or the sons visit the women's quarters and bring the Begum the news of the world of men outside. Then it is time to sleep again.     Purdah women often have as much to interest them in the management of their household as do their, emancipated sisters of the West. Nearly all Indian women attend personally to their households. Even the richest mother is not above preparing the vegetables for dinner. All Indian ladies know how to, cook and it is no disgrace to prepare the dinner with her own hands. In fact, when a husband particularly wants to- honour a guest his womenfolk will prepare the meal.     Some old families keep up the state of princes and petty kings.     There is one great lady who brightens her seclusion by surrounding herself by a bodyguard of amazons, women dressed as soldiers, who salute and present arms with military zest when her courtyard is entered by  visitor.

item.title: Five best movies to watch this weekend
item.dc:creator: sanjeevnjha
item.content:encoded:
Here we are back again with our list of  five movies to watch this weekend. This is an assorted list thrown together by memory and please do not try to find any connection or "running thread". We are not art critics. we do not offer any compelling reason to watch a movie beyond the fact that we liked it. So caveat emptor again, all our choices have our personal biases.  We are simple guys who just love movies.
 
6) Chung King express 
 
 
Chung King express is a big example of something that you like without being able to come up with any explanation as to why you like it. I am talking like a normal joe here. Of course, critics have explanations.
 
 
Movie critics will tell you that we all feel a sense of loneliness in today's urban existence even when we are surrounded by a sea of humanity. As per them, Chungking express manifests that contrast and strikes a chord with lot of urban dwellers. I have also read explanation of two cop stories and parallels between their love stories etc.  However I do not buy those arguments and  I do not get the depth in the story part either.
 
I believe Chung King express worked because no one was trying very hard to make it work. A good honest thing just happened. This movie was made when director was overworked from working on a magnum opus and just wanted to shoot a second movie to honor a contract. Tarantino was distributing this movie in the US. You can search his video on youtube. Tarantino does a fair bit of explaining about the making of this movie.
 
The movie is shot with a hand held at night and there are no sweeping panoramic scenes tricks with the camera. There is not much attempt to explain or develop the characters. Mostly you walk through a  a collage of frames and the movie works because the scenes in isolation works.
 
A lady in high heels wearing sunglasses at night shooting off a volley. A cop always buying a tin of pineapple with dates. Faye Wong swaying to "California Dreams" when cooking noodles and someone talking to the objects in his apartment. The scenes stick.
 
7) Back to the Future 
 
 
Lot of people believe that Science fiction has to be about science. You should drive at warp speed, laser cannons should evaporate planets to oblivion, everyone carries a voice operated device and robots should do all the chores. However good science fiction is almost never about explaining science. Good science fiction is about how we would behave and cope with new things at a future date.  Science just lurks in the background but needs no explaining.
 
 It is the human element that is interesting. Philip Dick stories are like that and so is "Back to The Future".  There is no need to explain how the professor invented the time device and the anomalies that would result from it. The sheer anachronism of someone from 1985 trying to fit in 1960 is the entertaining part. Twist open caps were not known in sixties and someone from eighties would fumble with a bottle opener. How do you avoid your mother making advances on you? How do you make sure that your mother and father meet and you are born? Add to that anachronism the usual school bullies, teenage  puppy love, a mad scientist and a janitor who would be a mayor and you have a sweet and mushy story. Time travel just happens in the background.
 
This movie has a nice rendition of "Johnny Be Goode by Chuck Berry (the original Rock-n-Roll star) " in the school prom scene.  Towards the end, the hero does some rock star twists and turns on floor and confesses to a shocked audience "you guys are not ready yet".
 
8  Double indemnity 
 
 
The risk in watching classic movies is that we do not have any idea of how it was when it was released. Just the other day someone was complaining about how cheesy the lines in Casablanca are. Now that classic became cheesy because of repetition. Those witty dialogues, those plot elements have appeared in so many guises before us that it is difficult to ascertain the original's effect.
 
Like, you may not be impressed with Jurassic park today because CGI has moved so much in meantime. You have already seen talking toys, cute ogres, flying houses and  suspend bullets. Walking dinosaurs are very cheesy today (especially after the disastorous sequels to Jurassic Park) However if I go back in time, I can still remember my jaws dropping alongside Laura Dern when those dinosaurs made their entry on screen.
 
Double indemnity was released in 1944 and we risk the contempt of familiarity with plot elements when watching it. However Double indemnity  manages to glue you to screen even today. The whole plot is unraveled in about 10 mins. An insurance agent trying to game the insurance company by enlisting help of a female love interest whose husband they murder. It was a very novel idea to reveal the murderer in first few minutes then. The beauty is, your interest in movie will not wane even after knowing the whole plot. That asserts my faith in adage that cinema is a visual medium. The plot is tight and the acting superb. I can say with confidence that there is not a single bore moment in this movie. All frames are related to the plot.
 
9) Perfume - The story of a murderer
 
 
The title is a bit extreme - it may suggest that this movie is about murderers and murders, a bit like those slap stick teen horror dramas. Just discard the murderer part from the title. Perfume belongs to the unusual story department. The kind of movies that is very dependent on script and are typically based on books. I do not want to play the spoiler and so won't tell you what this movie is all about. Few clues are one extraordinary sense, a trade, flowers, obsession with perfection and dead girls. If you can stand some extreme scenes then Perfume is a must watch. Especially keep your eyes open for the orgy scene in the end.
 
10) Harold and Kumar go to white castle
 
 
"Harold and Kumar Go to white castle" can safely be labeled a cult movie. There actually are people who swear by it. You can not classify this movie as "underground" like the Blair Witch Project but it was not a superstar cast either.
 
John Cho was in American Pie for about 3 seconds (see the stifler party scene again to spot him, according to IMDB, John, 'MILF' Guy #2) and in American Beauty for about 4 seconds. Kal Penn had worked in one of the Van Wylder series and few other I-drop-my-pants and-now-you-laugh comedies. He is also in Man About town with Ben Affleck. Danny Leiner is also the director of "Dude where is my car" (with  Ashton Kutcher) and that was a soaked to bone cheap comedy.
 
 So no one would have expected such a powerhouse performance from this ensemble. Maybe another pizza dropping from ceiling kind of hollywood comedy full of elephant riding indian  and kung fu hustling chinese characters but a deep satirical comedy. The only stereotypical scene is the one in Princeton about asian geeks. It is as if the director and two lead protagonists decided to rebel against the ordinariness bestowed on them before ( and after)  and decided to show the world what they are capable of. This movie has many classy scenes and dialogues.
  - Just because you are hung like a Mule does not mean you have to be a porn star - Are you boys going to f*ck me or what?
A marijuana smoking cheetah, white supremacist cops, A typical indian doctor dad, romantic song loving skin heads and a totally doped Neal Patrick Harris. This movie will not disappoint you. IMDB reports and opening weekend of $5,480,378 across 2135 Screens. For the records, it looks totally mainstream.

wp:comment.wp:comment_content: Great work! This is the type of info that are supposed to be shared around the web. Disgrace on Google for now not positioning this post higher! Come on over and visit my web site . Thank you =)

item.title: Pandit Jawaharlal Nehru Part one
item.dc:creator: sanjeevnjha
item.content:encoded: THE remarkable human being whose name is Pandit Jawaharlal Nehru is, next to Mr Gandhi, the most important Indian in India. This handsome, cultivated, and exceptionally fastidious and sensitive Kashmiri Brahman, who is stated to be the Mahatma's successor in the nationalist movement, is not so baffling a creature as Mr. Gandhi, but he has complexities enough. The struggle in Nehru is triple. He is an Indian who became a westerner; an aristocrat who became a socialist; an individualist who became a great mass leader. More than this, he is a man with a modern mind, a man of reason, a devout-if this is the proper adjective rationalist. And in India -the continent of caste and holy cattle, of religious fanaticism in an extreme degree-India, which is a sort of cesspool of rival faiths, but in which faith, any faith, is a paramount desideratum. Nehru the agnostic, Nehru the modern man, faces the colossal medievalism of India. He fights the British, but he fights the entrenched ritualism of his own people too. His position-in reverse-is roughly that of an American politician, say, who dared to come out against radios and two-car garages. His struggle is that of a twentieth-century mind trying to make a revolution of material that goes back beyond the Middle Ages. Think of the backdrop of the preceding chapters. This is the curtain on which Nehru has to write a modern, a contemporary story.   It is difficult to call him "Nehru," because in India he is universally known just as "Jawaharlal." Possibly this use of his first name became common in the early day's to distinguish him from his father.   The Nehru family, originating in the hills of Kashmir, settled first in Delhi, then Allahabad. One ancestor, Raj Kaul, was a Persian scholar in the good graces of the Mogul emperor of the time. The family name was Kaul for several hundred years; Nehru, which means "canal" was added later. Nehru's grand- father and great-grandfather both held posts under the last Moguls, and one of his uncles (like Gandhi's father) was a Dewan or prime minister of a small native state. When one says that Jawaharlal is a Kashmiri Brahman and the son of Motilal Nehru, it is as if one were to say that a man was a Boston Cabot or Lowell whose father was like Mr. Justice Holmes. He comes not only of the bluest blood in India, with a tremendous pride of race and heritage, but of a family with a deep tradition of public service and utility to the community. Young Nehru had an English tutor from his earliest years; in 1905, at 16, he went to England, where he studied at Harrow and Cambridge and read for the bar-curious, background for an Indian revolutionary! During this period his influences were largely literary. He was shy and lonely; he read Pater and Wilde and was devoted to what he calls a "vague kind of cyrenaicism, " though he came early in contact with social and scientific ideas. . In 1912, when he was 23, Jawaharlal returned to India. Life smote him promptly. It was in any case impossible for him not to be close" to politics-for instance the coalition between the Congress and the Moslem League in 1916 was made in his father's house-and he joined the nationalist movement. He met Mr. Gandhi ("All of us admired him for his heroic fight in South Africa, but he seemed very distant and different and unpolitical to many of us younger men") and soon made his first speech. He was dumb with shyness, and doubtful of his capacity even to speak his own tongue, Hindustani.  But after his talk the renowned leader Dr. Tej Bahadur Sapru , |rushed up on the platform and embraced him. Then came the Rowlatt Bills and Amritsar. Soon after, a turning point in Nehru's life occurred. He took his mother and wife, both of whom were ill, to Mussoorie in the north. It happened that an Afghan delegation, negotiating peace with Britain after the 1919 Afghan war, was housed in the same hotel. Nehru never talked to any of the Afghan plenipotentiaries, but after a month he was asked by the local police not to have any dealings with them. This struck him as being unreasonable; he had no intention of talking to the Afghans, but-a young man of spirit-he refused on principle to obey the order. Thereupon he was formally "externed" from the Mussoorie district. This was his first conflict with British authority. In the next two weeks he had nothing much to do, and as a result became aware of the kisans, peasants, and their grievances. The accident at Mussoorie helped turn him to the land. Already he had had vague socialist leanings. Now these began to be entrenched. With some colleagues he visited the peasants on their little farms. He saw their sufferings first-hand, and heard their grievances. He learnt to survive the Indian sun, and to speak to large gatherings. He discovered his capacity to arouse people. He even-unwittingly sent several peasants to gaol, because when they had been guilty of looting homes of landlords he-filled with Satyagraha spirit-demanded that they give themselves up to the police. "Many received long sentences and in later years, when I went to prison, I came across some of them, boys and young men, spending their youth in prison." Nehru first went to gaol during the 1921 non-cooperation campaign. This was the time of the first tremendous enthusiasm for civil disobedience, and hundreds of Indians, guilty of no crime or misdemeanour, fought for the privilege of being arrested. Young men and women mobbed the police lorries going through the streets, and scrambled to get inside the gaols. Altogether Jawaharlal has served seven terms in prison. Gaol 'or threat of gaol took the best years of his life. He was sentenced to an aggregate of  10 years; as several sentences were suspended, and he was discharged before time, so that he actually served five and a half years m all. The last sentence came as late as 1934, after civil disobedience had been called off; he was arrested following an alleged seditious speech in Calcutta, and given two years. Continually he brooded not merely on the nature of repression but on the fundamental reasons for it-reasons even beyond the political struggle in India. To test his courage he withstood a lathi charge and was bruised and beaten; his own .mother was likewise hit on the head with canes, and knocked down by the police; his wife followed him to gaol. He heard of such incredible sentences as that of the youth who got nine years rigorous imprisonment for carrying a revolver, and he knew schoolboys who were flogged in gaol for political offences. But his mind kept ranging over the particular. Gaol alone did not make him a socialist, but it gave him the time and opportunity for exhaustive political study and introspection. Generally he was well treated in gaol; he was permitted books and writing materials. His ideas on socialism took concrete form, and merged gradually with his nationalism. He began to see the Indian problem as more than a struggle between rebel nationalists and British nationalists. He became convinced that British imperialism as a capitalist growth was the real enemy, and that it must be fought from the socialist as well as from the nationalist point of view. British imperialism rests on capitalist exploitation as well as on the political demands of empire; therefore a logical opponent of British imperialism must be not merely a nationalist but a socialist too. This My True begotten Father His father, Motilal, was a very important influence on Jawaharlal, which is not surprising, considering how sensitive Jawaharlal was, and considering the vitality of the old man. Many important men have had great mothers. To find a great father passing on his qualities to his son is more unusual. The equation of the Nehru family worked both ways. Jawaharlal influenced Motilal almost as much as vice-versa. One is reminded of the psychoanalytic phenomenon of counter transference, wherein the patient attracts and influences the doctor, instead of the doctor attracting the patient. The youth, barely 20, began to drift towards extremism, towards rebellion. Motilal strove to understand his son, to check his drift away from him, which horrified him. At that time Motilal was a moderate; he had been a member of the Congress for years, but Congress was a very pale body in those days. Motilal wrote an article which Jawaharlal disagreed with; he chided his father by saying the British would approve it highly. Motilal was wild with rage. Yet Motilal's career depended largely on British policy and peace. Came Gandhi, and non-co-operation. Jawaharlal joined up. Motilal was dumb- founded. "He was not in the habit of being swept away by new proposals." He wasn't at all sure that civil disobedience would work; he resented it that his precious and beloved son should risk gaol. The conflict grew. "We tried to be as considerate to each other as possible. . . . Night after night I wandered about alone, tortured in mind and trying to, grope my way out." Then Jawaharlal discovered that Motilal was sleeping on the floor-to see what life in gaol would be like for his son. Within the year Motilal came over completely to his son's side. He took his stand with Gandhi and civil disobedience. This meant giving up his great house in Allahabad, his wealth, his practice; it meant giving up most of his friends, the political acquaintances with Indians and British alike, of a generation; it meant completely marking off his life at 60. And promptly old Motilal became the lion of the movement. When Jawaharlal went to gaol, his father went with him. For nine years the two worked together, fought together. Motilal was treated with the utmost consideration in prison, but imprisonment hurt his health. By 1930 he was an invalid. "He pulled himself together and banged the table in front him, saying that he had made up his mind to be an invalid no longer." But the machine was burnt out. "There he sat like an old lion mortally wounded and with his physical strength almost gone, but still very leonine and kingly." Sometime later Gandhi came to see him. Motilal said, "I am going soon Mahatmaji, and I shall hot be here to see Swarag. But I know that you have won it." Early in 1931 he died. Finally a curious thing happened. Returning home Nehru found a letter from his father awaiting him. It had been sent many months before, and had been forwarded and reforwarded without ever reaching the destination. And it was a letter of farewell. The Man Jawaharlal At 49 Nehru is strikingly handsome especially when he wears the Gandhi cap, a sort of white forage cap and he is one of those fortunate people who 'photograph even better than they look’. Usually he wears the Congress uniform -white khaddar and manages to appear courtly and Impressive even when shrouded with yards of cheesecloth apron. His friends say that he has aged a good deal in the past two or  three years, mostly as the result of fatigue, incessant travelling, and the giving out of energy. He is tall for an Indian-about five feet ten-with excellent bearing. He exercises methodically-and loves winter sports and swimming. He lives as a rule in a house called the Anand Bhavan at Allahabad. Motilal gave his tremendous house to the nation, renaming it Swarj Bhavan ; for the family he then built what -was to have been a simple cottage, but Motilal was an exceptionally expansive personality, and the simple cottage-the Anand Bhavan-where Nehru lives-turned into a house almost as big as the original one. The big house is now the headquarters of the Congress party; part of it is used as a hospital.

item.title: Pandit Jawaharlal Nehru Part two
item.dc:creator: sanjeevnjha
item.content:encoded: But Jawaharlal isn't in Allahabad very often. His travels are formidable. He lives on the railway trains, and by choice travels third class. Anyone who has been in India knows what an ordeal this is. Nehru's wife, Kamala, who came from a Kashmir Brahman family like his own, died in 1936. She had been in ill health for many years, and he was released from his last term of imprisonment in order to visit her in" Switzerland. Previously, when she was in India, the British volunteered to free him so that he might see her if he would pledge himself informally to give up politics for the period corresponding to the rest of his term. He refused. She begged him to refuse. Their only child, 20 -year-old Indira, is at school in England. "Nehru has two sisters; one, Lakshmi, married Ranjit S. Pandit and is the thoroughly competent minister for local self-government and health in the United Provinces Government-the first Congresswoman to reach ministerial rank. As a child she was called Sarup (the Beautiful One), and nicknamed Nan. His knowledge of English poetry is profound, and his love for it passionate. Incessantly he quotes classic verses. He has a great number of acquaintances, but very few intimate friends. He speaks often of his loneliness. He loves children, light-heartedness, laughter, but he is no backslapper; he hates, promiscuous effusiveness; he is moody and in- grown, and finds it hard to meet people half-way. They must come to him. He made even his father come to him-to meet his growing mind and soul. In one passage he says that he took to the crowd, and the crowd took to him, but that he was never able to lose himself completely to it; he was in it always, and of it never. This diffidence, this inner loneliness, is probably the mark of gaol. He detests ritualism and mysticism, except perhaps in poetry. Religion he calls a killjoy. He is all for modernisation, westernisation. "The spectacle of what is called religion, or at any rate organised religion, in India and else- where, has filled me with, horror, and I have frequently condemned it, and wished to make a clean sweep of it." This from an Indian leader! And there are many to say that his hatred of religion will keep him from supreme heights in India, because it is inconceivable that India should surrender herself finally to an agnostic. He has no faddisms, like the Mahatma. He ate meat from childhood, but gave it up, under Gandhi's influence, in 1920. He reverted to meat again in Europe, though he felt that it "coarsened him." Now (like Hitler, whom he in no other way resembles) he is "more-or-less" a vegetarian. He smokes occasionally, and, outside India, may even take a little light wine. His father drank wine-in fact, young Jawaharlal saw him with a glass once, and was thunderstruck-he thought old Motilal was drinking blood. His general health is so good that, even in gaol, he had no insomnia, he says. He has, however-, recorded some curious dreams. A favourite dream is of flying over open country. Once he dreamed that he was being strangled.He gets no salary for political work, and the family fortune has gone mostly to the cause. What little money he needs he gets from writing. The things he likes most are mountains, running water, children, glaciers, good conversation, and all animals except bats and centipedes. Once he had a moment of intense enjoyment in prison. The temperature was 116 degrees Farenhite, and his wife sent him a thermos flask filled with sherbert. The things he dislikes most are "exploitation, cruelty, and people who, in the name of God, truth, and the public good, are busy feathering their nests" -in a word, most politicians. He wrote to me recently: "I suppose my father and Gandhiji have been the chief personal influences in my life. But outside Influences do not carry me away. There is a tendency to resist being influenced. Still, influence do work slowly. He was influenced tor a time by Bertrand Russell, and then found him ineffective. He disliked Spengler at first, but found a "certain fascination" in his book. Nehru proceeds to say that Marx and Lenin had a powerful effect on him, partly from the content of their writings, even more by reason of the way they wrote. He was tired of mysticism and metaphysics; he liked the unadorned, scientific, analytical point of view. He says that he is certainly a socialist, in that he believes in socialist theory and method. His general approach is Marxist. But he wrote to me: "I am not communist chiefly because I resist the communist tendency to treat communism as a holy doctrine; I do not like being told what to think and do. I suppose I am too much of an individualist. ... I feel also that too much violence is associated with communist methods. The ends cannot be separated from the means." He likes moderation. He believes in the rational approach. He says of the Hindi-Urdu controversy: "Open the way of both scripts everywhere." As to communal troubles, which he thinks the British deliberately keep to the forefront, he says that the real struggle is not be- tween Hindu and Moslem, but between both and modern ideas. One of his defects, people say, is that he is too decent, too honourable, to be a good politician. He is a gentleman. Worse, he is an English gentleman! He has devoted his life to freeing India from Britain, but the British imprint is deep upon him. The old school tie has turned to homespun cheesecloth, and he still follows a code of chivalry. Another defect is, of course, his ingrown ness, his hatred of give-and-take and political hurly burly. The sources of his power are numerous. Consider, for instance, his courage and obvious strength of character. Then there is his technical competence at a job. He was, for instance, a successful mayor of Allahabad for a time. Consider, too, his industry, both intellectual and physical. In gaol, he not only wrote most of a closely-printed 617-page autobiography, but a history of the world in the form of letters to his daughter, 1,569 pages long. During the last election campaign he travelled 110,000 miles in 22 months, and reached villages everywhere in India. He used vehicles ranging from bullock carts to aeroplanes. He had to give up aero- planes because peasants in remote parts of the peninsula, never having seen a plane before, would overrun the landing fields. Once he made 150 speeches in one week. Then, again, there are his modesty and complete honesty with himself. By 1929 he was a hero, almost inundated by the applause and enthusiasm of the masses. By 1930 he had to face hero worship such as no man in India, Gandhi alone excepted,  had ever known. He writes that "only a saint or inhuman monster could survive" the praise that came his way without being a little, affected. He was distrustful of his popularity, but he couldn't help being exhilarated and impressed by it. His family quickly chastened him with raillery. His wife and sisters, and even his small daughter, began to call him in the home the names he was given by the crowd. They would say, "Oh, Jewel of India, what time is it?" or "Oh, Embodiment of Sacrifice, please pass the bread." His political integrity is unshakable. Nothing can deflect him from the path he has chosen, if he believes it to be right. He dislikes compromises, and he has nothing-of the occasional slipperiness of Mr. Gandhi. He makes definitions scrupulously, and abides by them. He is certainly one of the finest characters in public life I have ever met. He has great detachment. Recently this is a curious oblique sidelight on his character-he wrote a character sketch of himself, and carefully arranged so that it was published in a magazine anonymously. No one' knew that he was the author until he let the secret out to a few friends months later. Attitude to Gandhi Jawaharlal's relations to Gandhi are -more complex than those of a disciple to a master. Poles apart as they are mentally and emotionally, they are devoted to each other-recent rumours that they quarrelled are quite without foundation -and they complement each other nicely. Nehru needs Gandhi because Gandhi alone can carry the mass of the Indian people. Gandhi needs Nehru because he is his indispensable second-in-command. When Nehru first came in close contact with the Mahatma, he thought that in time Gandhi would turn gradually towards socialism. Years went by, and he saw his mistake. He worried terribly about it. It seemed to him an unreasonable paradox that Gandhiji, with all his "love and solicitude for the underdog," should "yet support a system which inevitably produces it and crushes it." He was impatient with Gandhi's ideas of trusteeship by the upper classes; he could not endure it that the Mahatma, who believed in non-violence, could support a sys- tem, capitalism, which was based on violence. Now he has given up Gandhi as incorrigible on this issue. Nehru, strictly speaking, is not the leader of the left in Congress. There are many others much more to the left than he is. He is not, oddly enough, even a member of the Congress Socialist party, a sort of autonomous block within Congress. This-another Indian paradox is partly because the organised and official socialists fear that his identification with them might embarrass his leadership of Congress as a whole. Jawaharlal holds an approximate left centre position, just as Mr. Gandhi is right centre. There are many Congressmen to the right of Gandhi. Sometimes young men in Congress think that, in the future, Jawaharlal may turn out to be Trotsky to Gandhi's Lenin. Jawaharlal himself quotes grimly a prophecy that he will someday be hanged by his own Congressmen. Nehru likewise differs basically from Gandhi in that he cannot follow his leader all the way on non-violence. He admits the political value of non-violence, but he says frankly that non-violence alone cannot carry India to the final goal. But what a beautiful warm and compelling picture he draws of Gandhi, what  a waterfall of tribute his pages are! He talks of his tremendous debt to Gandhi, “his amazing, irresistible and subtle charm over people, his “capacity to make heroes out of clay” ,his “inexhaustible reservoir – of spiritual power”. He , defends him vigorously against the socialists, who call him reactionary. "Reactionary or revolutionary, he has changed , the face of India, given pride and character to a cringing And demoralised people, built up strength and consciousness in the masses, and made the Indian problem a world problem." Relations to the British Nehru doesn't hate the British. He hates British imperialism' and its exploitation of India, but he freely admits " his intellectual debt to British culture”. When he takes a holiday, he heads straight for England. He has tried to forget the long agony of gaol, to dissociate the responsibility for it from Britain as a whole. The british should realise that the fact that he is a socialist-and a gentleman is a great asset on their side. Nehru, since he is a socialist, is impeded from any projection of the Indian struggle internationally, for the reason that the only countries which could help him are Fascist states, and he will have nothing, to do with them. The British are enormously curious about Nehru. They all know Gandhiji ; rather few know Jawaharlal. The pre- sent Viceroy, for instance, until the end of 1938 at least, had never met him. Everywhere one goes in India, the first political question is, "Have you seen Jawaharlal? What's he like? what's he doing- what's he up to now?"

item.title: Why Child Prodigies Often Fail
item.dc:creator: sanjeevnjha
item.content:encoded: EVERYBODY knows the brilliant child. He does well at school or answers difficult "quiz" questions, or plays the piano, or even distinguishes himself at chess, long before he might reasonably be expected to do so. And usually, after he leaves school, little more is heard of him. This article examines some of the reasons. Mathematical ability is one type of aptitude which does give evidence of being inherited fairly directly, and perhaps simply. For one thing, school records show a high correlation in the mathematics marks of fathers and sons, and of brothers.More significantly, we find phenomenal mathematical ability appearing quite spontaneously in young children.Many of the great mathematicians were prodigies, one of the greatest of all, Evariste Galois, having made all his important contributions before he was quite 21, when he was killed in a duel (in 1832).The great Gottfried Liebnitz was an- other mathematics prodigy, also writing on logic and philosophy when he was 14.Among contemporaries, one of the greatest American mathematicians, Dr. Norbert Wiener, graduated at 14.   Young Chess Prodigies JJUT while great mathematical ability may lead to high scientific achievement, it can do so only when coupled with creative and other capacities. Mathematical ability may be present independently of other mental powers.Thus, many phenomenal lightning calculators are of mediocre intelligence. One such case in 1945 was one of an 11-year-old boy who had unnusual capacities for memorising and playing musical compositions and for memorising and spelling words (without knowing their meaning). Chess prodigies offer further examples of a specialised form of mathematical ability and memory which appears to have a hereditary basis. Many of the greatest chess players revealed phenomenal capacities at early ages, among them Jose Capablanca, Paul Morphy, Rudolph Spielmann, and most recently Samuel Reshevsky (long national champion and still top-ranking chess player of the United States). Almost every chess master (with the exception of Akiba Rubinstein) learnt to play chess before  the age of ten.The case of Reshevsky has a personal interest for the author, who was starting his career as a "cub" reporter in Milwaukee in 1918 when Reshevsky, then eight years old, and newly arrived from Poland, carney to the city on a nation-wide exhibition match tour. The author was sent to interview the prodigy at a private home where he was being lodged. Loud outcries came from the rear yard.Investigation revealed a frail, under- sized youngster shouting at some neighbour lads in a language unintelligible to them that he was "The great chess player." In other words, the prodigy appeared to be no different from any other small boy. Yet, that night, we saw him suavely and single-handedly playing a simultaneous match with 30 adult and expert chess players, moving, with bewildering swiftness from board to board and in short order defeating all but two, who were declared tied because little Sammy was getting sleepy. In many prodigies only part of the mentality may be prematurely developed. A serious mistake, therefore, is to assume that the child has the adult intelligence that can come only with full biological and social maturity. By overlooking this, great harm can be done. One of the saddest examples was William James Sidis, son of a famed Harvard psychologist.  At the age of three young William could read and write; in six months he completed a seven-year public school course; at six he produced a treatise on anatomy; at eight, a new table of logarithms; at 14, he lectured at Harvard on the "fourth dimension." And then, at 20,he took the road to obscurity. In 1944, an unemployed clerk, he died at the age of 46. of a brain haemorrhage. Almost his last recorded words, in explaining his failure, were, "You know, I was born on April Fool's day." The fact that forced development of an exceptional child may lead to tragedy is being increasingly impressed on parents and educators, Are prodigies usually sickly, scrawny, squint-eyed, neurotic little kids, with bulging foreheads but no muscles? That is another long-popular notion blasted by Dr. Terman. When originally examined, those in the gifted group were found to be superior in health and physique to average children and taller and heavier for their age. Twenty-five years later, as adults, the "giftèd" group were found to have retained their initial superiority and their offspring were more than ordinarily bright. Varied Types WHEN we sum up our principal points about gifted children and prodigies, we may see that much con- fusion has resulted from thinking of them as of one type, whereas, actually, they are of a variety of types: 1. The "false" prodigy, who has no extraordinary mental equipment, but because of intensive early training by overzealous parents becomes a "mental athlete" who peters out later. 2. The "premature" prodigy whose overall mental equipment, while not basically superior, is merely speeded up in development (perhaps biologically), somewhat in the way that some children achieve early puberty, so that he is superior mentally to other children only for a time, until his development stops and he levels off as merely an average individual. 3. The "limited" prodigy who is endowed with only one or two special inherited capacities, such as a remarkable memory or mathematical ability, which may enable him to become a lightning calculator, an extraordinary chess player or a phenomenal student, but not much else. ' 4. The "true" prodigy, born with a brain exceptional in many ways, which, from childhood on, gives him superiority over other individuals and, in combination with the right environment, training, personality, etc., predisposes him to great achievement. In this last class are all the many prodigies who "made good" brilliantly for which he seemed destined in innumerable ways, such as Michel-angelo, Benjamin Franklin, Sir William Osier, Charles Darwin, Disraeli; the Mozarts, Handels, Beethovens, etc. So if you have a prodigy in your home, or think you have, it is well to be clear as to just what kind of prodigy you are dealing with.lt is also important to know that a child does not have to be a prodigy to be destined for greatness. Are degrees of sociability, aggressive- ness, timidity, fear, passivity, etc., inherited? Here are summaries of recent findings where behaviour reactions of animals were studied: Sociability: Sociability can be bred in dogs. Also, in mice, Dr. J. P. Scott has found that some breeds are much more sociable and peaceful with their fellows than others. . Fear: Instinctive fears among lower animals, of specific natural enemies or of specific situations, characterise each species. One interesting discovery by Dr. O, H. Hebb is that apes have a natural fear of inert or dismembered bodies-even of papier mache models of torsos or chimpanzee heads. Elephants have inherent fear of very small animals. Activity: Terriers, originally bred to kill rats and other vermin, are among the most nervous and active of breeds, with wire-haired terriers being some- what more so than Scotch terners. Oh the other hand, English pug dogs, bred originally as boudoir pets, are among the most passive and phlegmatic of canines, as are also Pekinese. Training has merely served to bring out inherited capacities. Can we apply any of the findings to human beings? There are marked differences in degrees of sociability, shyness, fear, aggressiveness, activity, etc.Perhaps, as in lower animals, these traits might in some ways, be linked . FEAR IN MAN appears to be little linked with genetic differences with genetic differences in brains, nerves, muscles, glands, senses, etc.

item.title: BAN ON DANCING GIRLS
item.dc:creator: sanjeevnjha
item.content:encoded: In the dimly lit stone cobbled temple hall, the girl pirouetted silently on bare feet, to the tune of haunting devotional songs sung by temple priests. Scores of butter-lamps flickered and fluttered, throwing ghostly shadows in the vast temple courtyard, as devotees, many clad only in loin cloths and sacred threads, watched the gaily clad girl's rhythmic dancing. At the end of the hall, in a stone-walled small room, a garlanded god— the stone idol deity of the temple— looked on with disinterested immobility at the congregation and the dancing girl. For the idol, it was a daily affair which had become a feature of the daily 'puja' 'worship for centuries. For the devotees gathered in the temple, the ceremony was perhaps the most effective at Invoking the blessing of the temple deity. For centuries, girls like the young one they were watching, had danced in the more important temples of South India to please the Idol and to invoke his blessing. Today the daily worship in the above temple , follows the century-old pattern, stipulated by ancient Hindu priests, but with one change. The dancing girl is no longer a feature of the daily worship. She is not even allowed to enter the temple precincts. The girl dancers, known in South India as Devadasis (servants of god) have been barred from practising their traditional occupation of dance worship in the temples by an order of the Government of Madras. The order, which came into force soon after Indian independence, says: 'Dancing by a woman, with or without Kumbhaharathy (sacred offerings) in the precincts of any temple or other religious institution or in any procession of a Hindu deity, idol or object of worship installed in any such temple or institution or at any festival or ceremony held in respect of such idol or object of worship is declared unlawful. Devadasis became the target of the wrath of government because their once-respected profession rapidly deteriorated in recent years and led to prostitution and immorality is temple surroundings. There are many In South India, however, who mourn the disappearance of the once-familiar dancing girl from their temples. They say that whatever be the justification for the ban on dance-worship by girls in Indian temples, the Devadasis were mainly responsible for the development of South Indian music and dancing. The ban- has put a set-back to the development of religious art, some say. Before the government ban came into force, in South India in 1947— (the dancing-girl worship is practised only in the temples of South India)— the temples In Madras and Andhra States in South India used to hold impressive ceremonies known as Sarati. Sarati consisted mainly of singing and dancing before the image as an invocation. It was performed at -the end of the main puja (worship) by Devadasis .When images were taken out in procession through the streets on annual fairs, the Devadasis led the procession— an unforgettable sight with the slender girls pirouetting through the thronging crowds, ahead of the slowly moving idol, flanked by pig-tailed Braham priests chanting hymns and burning incense. The origin of temple dancing in India can be tracked back to the Indus Valley civilisation, 4500 years ago. Relics discovered by Mohendodaro and Harappa excavations show that dancing for religious purposes was in vogue in those days. There is also evidence to show that the Devadasi dancing tradition had its roots in Indian cultural contacts with ancient Egyptian and Greek civilisations. In Greece, choruses sang hymns and danced for Apollo and the Muse who was an ardent patron of dancing was represented as the daughter tr Zeus. The dance-for- worship was practised by ancient Jews as well. Miriam danced to a song of god as an act of worship. David, too, danced before the Ark of God. Even the Psalmist says-: 'Praise ye the Lord. Praise Him with the timbrel and dance. In ancient India, dancing girls held very high positions.  During the reign of Emperor Chandragupta  Maurya, a contemporary of Alexander the Great, dancing girls were treated us a privileged class. They were specially selected for attending  the personal needs of the Emperor. Dancing girls held the royal umbrella when he rode in the son. Dancing girls stood behind the monarch, fanning him during the summer. Dancing girls poured out his drinks from golden pitchers whenever the king asked for a drink. In fact, most of the personal needs of the emperor had to be attended to only by the Devadasis. The ban on dancing girls is but one of the many steps taken by Indian authorities to check the growing traffic in women.

item.title: Miracle of Mohandas Karamchand Gandhi
item.dc:creator: sanjeevnjha
item.content:encoded: WHEREVER life, liberty and the pursuit of happiness are cherished as the inalienable rights of man, tiding of the death of this noble champion of the common people's cause has brought a sense of profound, stabbing grief not as for a remote, all-wise being far removed by his godlike stature from the joys and pains, the triumphs and defeats, of ordinary men and women, but with a feeling of intimate persona) sorrow as for a kind and loving father whose supreme genius, whose broad humanity and unique qualities of heart and mind, embraced his children in all the lands, and now are taken from them untimely, when , most sorely needed. To Understand the nature of this amazing man's, achievement, it is advisable first to consider, in broad outline, the ups-and-downs of his career. How chanced it that his followers, who in 1914 numbered only seven, had grown to 340,000,000 by the time of his death? What was it that raised a man of obscure birth, of no family influence, and of delicate constitution, to such a pinnacle as the Mahatma reached? Mohandas Karamchand Gandhi, born at Porbandar, Kathiawar, on October 2, 1869, was edu- cated at Rajkot in his early years. He was married at the age of 13, and at 18, already a father, began to study law at the University of London, where he gained his LL.D. Having qualified, too, as a barrister of the Inner Temple, he practised law in Bombay and in South Africa, where he championed the cause of his oppressed fellow nationals living there, it did not embitter him that he, a British barrister, was thrown out of a train in the Wilds of Africa, bag and baggage, either to perish or to tramp his way to some distant habitation-and all because he was Indian born! No protection was afforded him by the British Government. No protest was raised by the Inns of Court. During the Boer War and the Zulu uprising in Natal Gandhi led and Indian Ambulance Corps. Then he went to England to plead the cause of the Indians in Africa. He maintained that the Boers had got generous treatment because they had fought against England and dared the atbitrament of war, while the East Indians could get no hearing because they had only appealed to the forum of Ethics and Justice. He formed committees; he interviewed statesmen; he spent his days and half his nights writing, interviewing and pressing for the fulfilment of the pledge of citizenship for the Indians in Africa-but in vain In the first German War Gandhi again organised an ambulance corps, and conducted a vigorous recruiting campaign. Soon after 1918 he assumed the leadership of the indian Nationalist movement, introducing quite new methods. He rejected armed rebellion and recommended the overthrow of the British Raj through the peaceful methods of non-cooperation and non- violent civil disobedience (satyagraha). This conception transferred Tolstoy's anarchistic ideas from the field of social revolution to that of national emancipation; it was a typical expression of the unbellicose, somewhat passive southern Hindu mentality, which believes in the ultimate triumph of soul force over brute force. Spiritual Leadership THE Indian Nationalist movement spread with extraordinary rapidity, and Gandhi, attaining enormous prestige among his followers, emerged as a major political force. He became the worst headache the-Government had experienced. Again and again he was thrown into gaol; the curious notion developed in the Official mind that to separate the reformer from his followers would result in a weakening of their allegiance, It was a notable instance of folly in high places, for Gandhi's influence was increased immeasurably with each successive term of imprisonment, the effect on the masses being exactly the reverse of what officialdom intended. The tale of Gandhi's sufferings, of his patient and uncomplaining fortitude in adversity, enhanced the reverence, the worship even, which was accorded him throughout the land. The untouchables," for whose, betterment he fought with unremitting passion and vigour, came to regard him as a deity, a reincarnation of Brahma the give of life, waging relentless war against Shiva, its destroyer. The idea of a man being worshipped in his lifetime seems almost ludicrous to the Western .mind. But - why not? Why wait until he is dead before recognising a man's character and paying him the honour that is due to him? Is it because we judge the saintly mind by the political yard measure, and fear lest adoration would so transform the character that a being who was, today worshipped for his sanctity might tomorrow demonstrate that his feet were of clay? But Gandhi was no clay-footed idol. Certainly he was a problem. To rulers and governors he was a thorn in the side. To logicians he was a fool. To economists he was a hopeless ignoramus. To materialists he was an unpractical visionary To Communists he was a drag on the wheel. To constitutionalists he was a rank revolutionary. Moulder of Destiny FROM time to time the most reliable Press correspondents informed their editors that Gandhi’s power had passed, that his authority had waned, that he was no longer a living force in his own land. A few days later his name had a habit of appearing once more in large type, and his opinions and his directions were quoted and discussed on the ground that they would alter the minds and actions of millions of men-not his own Hindus alone, but innumerable Moslems too. His influence as a reformer, as a tireless crusading politician, was exceeded only by his ascendancy as a spiritual leader. Perhaps the secret of this power was that every- one knew that he practised what he preached. His proclamation or the doctrine of the simple life was very far from being mere lip-service. His frequent fasts, the austere, rigid asceticism of his whole existence, were no whims or eccentricities; they sprang from deep inner conviction. Apart from religion, his great rule of life was obedience to the vows which he took at his mother’s knee before she sent out her young lad into an unknown, fearsome world where the cherished rules of her faith were despised and treated as heathen superstition. There is no saint that has been placed in Christian hagiology since the time of the Apostles who could be invoked to mould men's actions - today to the same extent that the Mahatma Gandhi could influence the teeming millions of India who, divided on most things by barriers of caste and sect, were as one in owning their willing allegiance to this simple, thin ,wizened old man. Sovereignty Secure HE ruled hot as kings rule and his governance was not that of princes; his men-at-arms were mild-eyed lambs, his trumpeters the birds; no blaze of glory his, for he mistrusted all pomps and panoplies; his tones, his wise, well loved words of encouragement or admonition or rebuke,came not as storm borne thunder-peals, but as a still, small voice. Now that voice is forever mute, and the brave heart beats no longer in the bullet-shattered breast. But the memory of Mahatma Gandhi, of the deeds he did and the words he spoke and the man he was, will remain a continuing inspiration-and a challenge to all men of goodwill to go and do likewise-until the last wave breaks on Time's farthest shore and the world's dusk darkens into endless night.

item.title: Romancing the TEA
item.dc:creator: sanjeevnjha
item.content:encoded: A long time ago a WM.H UKERS set out to write a book, "All About Tea," and he intended to confine it to One volume. His opening remarks, however, show that the topic got away from him, for it took him ten years to complete the job, which ran into two volumes. He wrote 54 chapters, containing 600000 words, and among other things, a tea chronology containing 500 dates of historical importance, a tea bibliography containing the names of 2,000 authors, a tea dictionary of 425 definitions, and an index of 10,000 references. It was not until the latter half of the seventeenth century that tea began to obtain a footing in England. Pepys records, under date September 25, 1661, "I sent for a cup of tea (a China drink) of which I  had never drunk before." Three years later the East India Company bought 221b. 2 oz. of tea as a present for King Charles II. Tea appears to have been originally imported in small quantities by the Dutch, and at the time of the Restoration it began to be used in coffee houses. In an Act passed in 1660, a duty of 8d. was imposed on every gallon of "coffee, chocolate, sherbet and tea" made and sold. In 1842, the home consumption of tea in the United Kingdom was close upon 37  million lb., out of imports totalling 40 million lb., on which over £4,000,000 in duty was paid. Just before the war in 1938, the import of tea into Great Britain reached the staggering total of 526,691,303 1b., valued at £30,798,915. Price Scandals UNTIL about 113 years ago, the trade in tea was monopolised by the East India Company. By limiting the quantity brought to market and fixing its own price, the company made immense profits, it is recorded that the tea sold by the company during the last years of the monopoly cost the people of Britain upwards of £1,500,000 a year more than it would have cost had it been sold at the price at which teas of equal quality we're sold under a system of free competition in New York,Amsterdam and other cities. There were so many scandals over the prices charged that in 1883 a Bill was passed making it lawful for all individuals to import tea. The use of tea is reputed to go back to 2737 B.C., and there is an alleged Confucian reference to it in 550 B.C. The earliest credible mention of it is A.D. 350, and it is claimed that Nature's original tea garden was in south- eastern Asia. The first handbook on tea is the Cha Ching, written about 780 A.D., and the earliest mention of tea in the literature of Europe was in 1559. If we omit two small gifts of tea for the English King in 1664 and 1666, the first importation of tea by the East India Company was in 1669, when 143 lb. were brought from Bantam in Java. Thus began the importation into England of a commodity which in time was to build fortunes and to dot the sea with tea ships about which hundreds of romantic stories have been written. The fascinating story of what has been called "The Golden Age of the Clipper Ships" has often been told, for the vast extent of the tea trade revolutionised shipping in England and America. In the days of the clippers, speed was the essential factor. The fortunes of the merchants depended upon the rapidity with which the tea could be brought to the market. Shipping annals are full of the details of the races of the rival ships across the ocean. Thou- sands of people waited on the wharves to welcome the tea-laden vessels from the East. The Tea Clippers THE most exciting of all tea races started on May 28, 1866, from the Pagoda anchor- age in the Min River, below Foochow, and, ended 99 days later in the London docks, and fortunes were made and lost on the result. Eleven ships, all first-class tea clippers, sailed from the anchorage. The race is described in detail by Ukers in his "All About Tea." The positions of the various ships at every stage of the voyage are given meticulously, and a slight lead of an hour or two would cause a flutter in the offices of the tea merchants. Two of the clippers, the Ariel and the Tae ping, were at length reported to have arrived in the English Channel almost simultaneously, and were racing neck and neck, to reach the Lon- don docks. The race was not finished until the sample boxes of tea-were hurled ashore on the wharves, and so scared were the owners of the Ariel and the Taeping of losing 10/ extra a ton on a quibble as to which ship really won, that they agreed privately to divide the premium. It is said that the interest and excitement among landsmen during the clipper ship days has been rivalled only by the Derby. Their racing at that time was the topic on 'Change, at the club and by the fireside. Gold, tin, rubber and oil booms fade into insignificance when compared with tea as a speculative commodity on the London market. The first company to be formed was the Assam Company in 1839. The Jorehaut Tea Company, formed in 1859, held a remarkable record. During 73 years it only thrice missed paying dividends: the 100th dividend was paid in 1927. The highest annual dividend paid by any company in the pre-war period was 130 per cent, free of tax, the equivalent of 150 per cent, less 20 per cent tax paid in 1922 to shareholders of the Ghoir Allie Tea Company Ltd. Dividends of 75 per cent to 80 per cent and even higher were by no means uncommon.

item.title: A 1950 article on TATA
item.dc:creator: sanjeevnjha
item.content:encoded: In A Backward Country, The House Of  Tata Has Accomplished Miracles MODERN industry presents no more romantic story than the rise of the House of Tata, the gigantic business organisation with headquarters at Bombay, which has proved the backbone of India's industrial effort during this present war, just as it was during the previous war.   Tata's development is a  miracle of achievement in a notoriously backward country.   For evidence of the wide ramifications of the Tata enterprises it is only necessary to glance at the Bombay telephone book where the name of Tata occupies a half-page. The House of Tata has its own telephone book for use in the many offices of its various offshoots. But the men at the helm of Tata are not satisfied that India has been able to do her best industrially during the present war Listen to the chairman of the parent body. Tata Sons. Ltd. 40 -year-old. handsome, polished, 'capable son of an Indian father and a French mother, J. R. D. Tata- "There is much glib talk about India's tremendous industrial expansion brought about by war needs, and about the foundation having been laid for the future. The change in the position regarding sterling balances appears to have contributed to this impression. Actually, there is little or no creation of new industries. Indian industries have not been permitted to expand, as, for example, industries in Australia and Canada. "Take aircraft manufacture and shipbuilding. Surely we could have done much in this direction. Just as Australia bas done All that has happened is that existing businesses have increased their ' production. On the other hand, many new enterprises have received a setback during the war. The completion of our own chemical works, started before the outbreak of war was greatly delayed as a result of -the war, and even now shortage of coal is holding up production- Actually, then, the war has hampered rather than assisted the progress of India's indus trialisation." The story of the House of Tata is the story of industrial growth in India, and the central figure is the stalwart- old pioneer, Jamsedji Nusserwanji Tata, who lived from 1839 to 1904.   He was a Parsee. There are only 100.000 Parsees in India, the majority of them in Bombay province; but though small in numbers, they have exercised a dominating influence in the commercial and political spheres of Indian life, because of their business acumen and the manner in which they have kept pace with Western civilisation. Such a one was J. N. Tata, who, however, combined intense patriotism and a true philanthropic sense with extraordinary vision and that attention to detail that marks the genius. There are statue, and busts of this "grand old man'' studded around Bombay's sweeping avenues; but his greatest monument is the House of Tata. He had to overcome business depressions and he had to combat prejudice; but he laid the solid foundation on which his successors have built. He did not live to see all his schemes brought to fruition; but his was the mind that envisaged many of Tata's modern undertakings.   Such an arrangement is common in India, where industrial organisation is not widespread and the good name -of a promoter means almost everything to an investor. Control is firmly held by the Tatas, however , for Tata Sons, Ltd. owns blocks of shares in various offshoots. Individual members of the Tata family possess 15 p.c, of Tata Sons stock; the remaining 85 percent, is distributed among charities controlled by trustees.   The first Tata company was promoted by the pioneering Jamshedji in 1637. His interest then was cotton, and he established the Empress Mills at Nagpur in the centre of a cotton-growing belt. He had to pay for experience: but he made good after early years of straggles with decrepit machinery, and now the Empress is an extra ordinarily flourishing concern, five mills running 120,000 spindles and 2,200 looms. J. N. Tata followed with the Swadeshi mills, at tbe time of the Swadeshi campaign ("made in India"). Here be aimed at producing finer yarns and so stoutly entered into competition with Lancashire.   After grave initial setbacks, his courage and perseverance won out, and he put Swadeshi on a sound footing. He added the Advance Mills at Abmedabad and his successors have established the Tata Mills. Ltd. The four or ganisations combine to play a tremendous part in the textile industry of India.  J. N. Tata gathered in much property around his beloved Bombay. He erected the palatial Taj Mahal Hotel, which stands as a landmark just beyond the Gate way to India. The city, be felt, needed an hotel of the majestic type which would attract wealthy tourists. "JN" died before his dreams of a steelworks, a hydro-electric scheme and a scientific research institute had come into reality; but they all stand now as a testimony to his vision.   The Tata Iron and Steel Works, under the guidance of American experts and with American plant, sprang up out of the jungle village of Jamshedpur ISO miles from Calcutta,in 1907. J. N. Tata had given his American advisers a free hand in selecting a site and finally they chose this area situated equidistant from iron ore deposits and from essential coal fields. Many blue prints have since come from America, and the area of the steel works has spread enormously.   Tatas claim them to be the largest single unit steel works in the British Empire. The full operation. from the production of pig iron to the manufacture of finished steel, takes place at- Jamshedpur. The blast furnaces were fully in operation a few years before the first World War and Tatas produced some 300,000 tons of steel for use by the Allies in the Middle East and East Africa. The present output is mammoth, but figures are not available for publication. At the outbreak of the war against Japan, however, the Tata Iron and Steel Works were producing about 13000000 tons of pig iron, 1100000 tons of steel ingots, and over 800000 tons of rolled products for the market.   Industry in Bombay owes a great deal to the three great hydro-electric schemes which have grown from the original project of J. N. Tata. They supply power, not only to the textile mills and other industrial undertakings, but to Bombay's modern transport, including two railways, and to various power distributing companies serving this city of  2000000 people.   Five dams harness the waters in the valleys of the Western Ghats, a chain of hills rising to 4.000 ft. about 50 miles east of Bombay. Such conservation is necessary, as rainfall in the province normally extends over little more than three months, when the south-west monsoon prevails. The Tata Oil Mills produce cheap vegetable oils for bulk export; they have solved a problem for the Indian housewife by the production of vast quantities of household and toilet soaps from indigenous materials. Production of cement has also engaged the attention of the Tatas. Comparatively recent stepping stones in their march of progress have been the pioneering of commercial aviation in India, the establishment of a chemical company for the production of heavy chemicals, which is expected to prove a boon after the war if organised effort is made to rehabilitate the stagnating agricultural industry, and the creation of an Investment Corporation, to encourage the promotion of worthwhile Industrial ventures and to advise investors. There are also innumerable subsidiary concerns in which Tatas are financially interested, without having control, such as insurance company and banks.   Tatas are proud of their performances in the field of welfare work among their employees, a side of industry often neglected in this densely populated country. In the great steel mills area Tatas have assisted workmen to own their own homes, have erected free hospitals and clinics, and recreation rooms. A teaching staff of more than 400 instructs in English and various Indian dialects in 44 schools run by the company  there are also municipal schools). Their worth is shown by the fact that while the percentage of literacy in India is only 10 per cent among the 150.000 inhabitants of Jamshedpur district the percentage is 70 per cent.   The Indian Institute of Scientific Research at Bangalore magnificently equipped, is a famed centre of learning, and the Tata Scholarship Trust, conceived by J. N. Tata, has enabled many deserving Indian students to pursue their studies abroad, and eventually to win their places in professional and scientific organisations. As the profits continue to roll into the House of Tata, so do Tata charities enlarge their scope, and thus this great concern is an ever-increasiag national asset.   Tatas have been fortunate in the men holding the reins.  J. N. Tata's sons, Sir Dorab and Sir Ratan, consolidated their father's - work. Both died childless. and their main direction of activities devolved upon R. D. Tata, son of , an adopted son of Sorab Tata, who was a cousin of J. N. The present chairman, J. R. D. Tata, a son of RD, succeeded the late Sir Nowroji Saklatavala in 1838. He takes a special interest in the steel works, the chemical company and aircraft and airlines companies. He was the first pilot to qualify in India, and has held a flying licence since 1929.   The influence of the House of  Tata -was emphasised by the publication of the now famous Bombay Plan for the economic development of India. Four of the eight signatories were Tata directors.

item.title: Patel Was India's Man Of Iron
item.dc:creator: sanjeevnjha
item.content:encoded: The death of  Sardar Valabhai Patel, India's Deputy Prime Minister, on December 15, removed from the political stage of Asia one of its most interesting actors. Patel-the man who looked like a living bust of Plato, spoke with the cool deliberation of an Asquith and acted with the ruthless energy of a Bismarck-was not only India's second most important leader, but also typified a class and an ideology. He was the East's leading anti-Communist-nationalist. Patel was an important figure long before India emerged from colonial status, though it was since then that he had really come into his own. His greatest political achievement was the reformation, unification, and consolidation of India's princely States, of which, in 1947, there were some 300. By the time Patel had finished, barely a dozen of any significance were left. Patel was the architect of the "police action" against Hyderabad, but this was the only case where force had to be used. He achieved his monumental success by persuading the princes that the new India would respect their traditions. Patel was nothing if not a conservative. The son of a land-owning family in the north, he fell under Gandhi's influence in the twenties.Yet he was a Gandhian only in a restricted sense. Prison courting and intimate village uplift work did not appeal to his logical nature. A formidable organizer, he made economic boycott into a sharp-edged  weapon.  It was his organising ability and the supreme confidence which industrialists reposed in him which placed him into a position to become the chief defender of "law and  order" after the change-over.
