He became the counterweight to the more emotional and incalculable Nehru. Disciple Of Gandhi Patel was a disciple of the Mahatma, but before his death Gandhi and Patel quarrelled. Gandhi suspected him of wishing to match the spirit of the Moslem League, out of which Pakistan was born, with a policy of Hindu aggressiveness. At one point he threatened that Congress was too small to hold both Gandhi and a Patel. But Gandhi died. The Punjab massacres drenched India in blood, and the man of iron, the tireless worker, was given his opportunity. His job was to tame the princes and to crush the Communists. Old and ill and frugal, he traveled the country, exhorting the  people to accept and maintain traditional morality. At the same time he armed the police as they  had never been armed before. He was an extraordinary sight in any assembly-an immobile face, a towel-like scarf flung over his shoulder, strong, bare, sandal-clad legs. Nehru and Patel-they were a remarkable pair. In the early days of the new Government they watched each other warily. It was only the fact that Nehru was indispensable as a popular tribune that prevented the forces behind Patel from attempting to oust him.The alliance of the two was cemented by the murder of Gandhi, which, for the time being, completely discredited the militant partisans of  Hindu exclusiveness. Political Reality The Nehru-Patel "axis" increasingly represented political reality- the union of all forces, liberal and conservative, entrenched against the revolution. Patel's services in the anti-Communist war were immense. In the big rising of the Indian sailors at Bombay and Karachi just prior to the Cripps mission, it was Patel who hurried to Bombay and flung the influence of Congress against the mutineers. Last year it was Patel who gave the final orders when the Indian Regular Army was sent to beat down the smouldering revolt in the agrarian districts on the borders of Mysore, Madras, and Hyderabad. He did not shrink from filling the prisons. Patel was always careful to insist that he did not meddle in foreign affairs. All the same, he was a close friend of Loy Henderson, the American Ambassador. It was his view that India could not remain neutral and that she must align herself with the United States. His death removes a powerful check on Nehru's policy of relative neutrality. In 1947 India had only one choice: that of a triumvirate of Gandhi, Nehru, and Patel. After that, the Nehru-Patel combination was the only one possible. Now Nehru is alone. Patel, enigmatic comrade, has left him the machine that guarantees the status quo in India. .Before his death, the Sardar made sure of a potential successor. He saw to it that a safe, "strong man was put in charge of the Congress party-the most powerful in Asia, apart from the Chinese Communist Party.  The name of that man - a Babu Purshottamdas Tandon.

item.title: It happened only in India
item.dc:creator: sanjeevnjha
item.content:encoded: UNAFFECTED BY POISON Hindu Mystic puzzled Noble Prize Winner Under the strictest scientific, supervision, including that of Sir C. V. Raman, the eminent scientist, Nraasingh Swami, a Hindu mystic of Madras, gave a remarkable demonstration at Calcutta of poison swallowing. He took concentrated doses of deadly poisons such as potassium cyanide and mixed the diet with pieces of glass and nails. The mystic was apparently, unaffected. The glass and nails were later located by X ray. Sir C. V. Raman confessed that he was mystified. He said that it was a challenge to modern science. SKELETON WORSHIP   Maharajah Martanda Harma , who was a Brahmin, developed a keen interest in physiology. With the help of a skeleton, which the court surgeon  Dr Brown,  presented, the Prince learned anatomy. Soon the news spread that the Mararajah had defiled his sacred body by touching bones. The Brahmins protested, and the people marched on the palace, demanding that the ruler should abandon his study. The Prince refused, and a revolution was imminent, when an old craftsman advanced, and told the Maharajah that he could make a perfect ivory replica of the skeleton. This satisfied the Brahmins, since it was no sin to touch ivory. The replica cost £5,000 at that time. STRANGE CEREMONY IN INDIA : Hook Swinging     Ten thousand people, including the Governor of Pondicherry and other French officials, regularly attended one of India's 'strangest ceremonies- hook swinging-in the Mariamman Temple at "Kadirkaman, near Pondicherry. Hook-swinging, a form of self-torture in worship Of Mariamman, the Goddess of Small-pox, was much practised by Indian devotees in the Madras Presidency until the British authorities banned it . So powerful was the cult that in 1934, when the ban was enforced, riots broke in which a magistrate and two police officers were killed. In this ceremony the self-appointed victim was slapped hard on the back until he was numb. Then two iron hooks were inserted just below the shoulder blade. With ropes attached to the hooks the man was swung a lot on a pole tied across another pole. The victim was then rotated while the hooks tear his flesh. Murder by Coconut   In a school at Harnhalli (South India) a text book was stolen; so the master lined up the students and told them that when the thief touched an enchanted cocoanut on his table he would be visited by divine wrath. All the boys except one, Basavappa, touched the cocoanut, but Basavappa said he did not believe in such nonsense. The master, however, forced him to touch the cocoanut and then work was resumed.

item.title: Indian thuggee cult of assassins
item.dc:creator: sanjeevnjha
item.content:encoded: The genuine Thugs are extinct; they were nearly all wiped out a century ago. But in their heyday they murdered, according to plausible estimates, well over a million people . USUALLY three went to work on each victims, and their technique was a beautiful -demonstration of the team-spirit. One would grab the victim's arms, another his legs. By scientific twists and jabs they threw him forward on to his face in a couple of seconds. At the same time the leader of the party neatly threw a strip of doth, called a ruhmal round the vic tim’s neck from behind, and while the others held him down strangled him. Thugs also made a special study of the art of burying bodies. In half an hour a party could dig a grave, put a body in it, and replace the earth so skilfully that they, themselves could; only find the grave after wards by reference to landmarks. (Before burying a body they Blabbed it thoroughly with their knives so that it would not swell later and cause the surface of the ground to rise.) .   The Thugs kept their trade secrets very well. Although they had worked in India for centuries , very little was known about them until the British began a campaign to clean them up. The task of investigating them was given 1829 to Captain William Sleeman, an officer of the Indian Army. Judged by the Scale of its results, the work he did in the next 12 years was per haps the greatest piece of crime detection in history. Sleeman had unlimited energy  and courage, and he was also a Very intelligent man. By the efforts of him and his staff, 4600 Thugs were arrested. About 500 were hanged; most of the remainder were imprisoned for life. Among, them were aces like Burham, who strangled 931 people in an active ( career of 41 years), Futty  Khan, who strangled 508 in  21 years, and Rantzam, whose final score was 604.   Sleeman was the first European to discover that the Thugs were an hereditary highly or ganised religious fraternity. They worshipped an unpleasant goddess called Bhawani, and re garded their murders as a ritual human sacrifice to her. It was a part-time religion, which Hindus and Mohammedans could practise as a sideline. Thugs also made their murders a source of income, as they robbed their victims. But above all they considered strangling an exerting sport. It thus provided them with a combination of piety, profit, and pleasure. Sleeman succeeded in breaking the system wide open by one of the classical police methods. . He persuaded -a number of key thugs to turn King's evidence — as the New York police say, he made them sing. In return for their services' these renegade thugs, known, as 'approvers', were punished by imprisonment instead of hanging. In 1830 , Thug leader named Feringeea was arrested. He told Sleeman that if his life was spared he could give information that would lead to the rounding up of several Thug gangs. To prove that he knew what he was talking about Feringeea offered to show Sleeman where one of these gangs had buried some bodies. The place he named was a village in Bengal called Selohda. Sleeman sent a party of men ahead, and  they made camp in a mango grove outside this village. In the evening Sleeman arrived and went to bed in his tent. Next morning he had Feringeea brought in and told him to locate the bodies. Feringeea said they were right on the spot, and at his direction the party dug underneath Sleeman's tent. They unearthed the bodies of a merchant and six servants, and a woman who had been murdered twelve years before. A few yards sway they dug up the remains of five soldiers. Having established his bona fides in this impressive manner, Feringeea became Sleeman’s most valuable source of information about Thuggee. As a rule, Sleeman learned, Thugs worked in gangs of twenty to fifty men. Strung in groups along a road, they pretended to be harmless wayfarers and did not carry -any obvious weapons. They took elaborate pains to win the 'confidence of travellers, with a view to strangling them. If they decided to go to work on a large party several groups would coalesce without giving any sign that- they knew one another. The biggest single operation in Thug memory was the 'Sixty Soul Affair.' carried out in 1801. In this coup a gang of over 200 Thugs strangled 52 men, seven women and a child.     On another occasion a party of Thugs became friendly with some travellers on a road in the kingdom of Oudh. When they came to a camping site one of the Thugs pretended to be violently ill and groaned with pain. Another Thug said he knew & magic cure for this complaint; everything would come right, he said if the party would sit down around a bowl of water and look up and count the stars. The travellers, who seem to have been naive individuals, did this; a minute later the ruhmals were put to work. (The ruhmal was a piece of yellow and white cloth about two feet six inches long, with a slip knot tied in it. After a team of them had thrown a victim forward on to the ground with a ruhmal round his neck the strangler threw second loop of it round the neck. Then he put his foot against the neck to give more purchase' as he pulled the ruhmal tight!) In studying the careers of individual Thugs, Sleeman found that many of them were Jeckyll and-Hyde characters. Most of the year they worked as respectable citizens— shopkeepers, ser vants, or clerks. .Then for a few weeks they took a holiday without pay. They made a secret rendezvous with a gang of friends, and set out on a Thug expedition. One case that came to Sleeman's notice was that of an Indian servant employed - by an English doctor named Cheeky to look after his children. He was gentle and considerate, and the children became very fond of him. Every year he asked for four weeks leave to visit his old mother, and it was later proved that he  spent this month strangling people. Because Thuggee ran in families, Sleeman took great trouble to locate the relatives of men identified as Thugs. He and his staff worked out genealogical trees of Thug families for several generations. He recognized that the Government could not stamp out the cult unless the Thug families became extinct. For this -reason the sons of Thugs, if too young to have begun killing, were kept in life long confinement without access to women. The conditions of their imprisonment were not otherwise severe, and they were employed in tent and carpet making. It was a ruthless policy, but had the desired effect. During his investigations Sleeman unearthed several sub classes of Thugs. Among these were the River Thugs who conducted amphibious operations around the Ganges; they special ised in luring travellers from riverside roads on to boats, killing them, and dumping the bodies into the water. Another and particularly odious sub-class of Thugs were known as Magpunnists. These, strangled parents in order to take their children. The boys they obtained were sold as slave workers and the girls were sold to houses of prostitution. Thuge, not necessarily Magpunnists, often kept the  girl children of their victims and later married them. One gang leader boasted to Sleeman that no women were more faithful to their husbands than the wives of Thugs. Sleeman thought this was true, and for good reasons. Indians thought twice before making a pass at the wife of a Thug, and the wives themselves had considerable respect for the ruhmal. In the normal way of business Thugs never killed Europeans. But when the news of Sleeman's activities had spread through India he went in constant danger of his life. Three attempts in all were, made to murder him, though not by means of the ruhmal. After 12 years work Sleeman banded over control, of the Department for the Suppression of Thuggee to a successor. The department remained in existence until the 1880's, but strangling cases were only sporadic. The Thug system had been virtually eradicated by Sleeman.

item.title: Understanding hinduism and mysticism part one
item.dc:creator: sanjeevnjha
item.content:encoded: YOGA AND HARE KRISHNA ARE FACETS OF THE HINDU RELIGION THAT FASCINATE THE WEST – BUT WHAT ARE THE FACTS BEHIND THE FASCINATION? THE men who started the whole business would probably think it a pity I can write and you can read. They could do neither. They taught their doctrine  in private conversation, and the doctrine was simple enough. lt said that if you had the patience to go off and think about yourself for a long time, you would end up not giving a damn about anybody or anything, including—and here was the   surprise—yourself. I have stated their teachings in common language. They used the  same means. They did not speak Sanskrit, as people wrongly suppose: they taught in Prakrit, a popular vernacular. Sanskrit was  used by the Brahmans, who were priests. The founders of Hindu mysticism detested and despised the Brahmans, considering them to be little better than charlatans. LITERARY LANGUAGE Just when these founders taught is not known, but it must have been well before 400 BC, because by then their revolt against the priesthood had become   fashionable. The literary men of that time decided to write down what was remembered of the founders'  teachings. Unfortunately for us, they deeded to write in a literary language. Sanskrit is elaborate and often very beautiful, and is perhaps the finest medium ever devised for showing off a writer's sense of style. The result was a series of   short books called the Upanishads. The writers of   these books were masters of Sanskrit poetry and prose, and for two thousand years more nonsense has been written and spoken about the   Upanishads than virtually any set of books in existence. The attempt to translate the words of the sages into stylish Sanskrit was equivalent to asking Gibbon to rewrite the Gospels. Some- thing of the story would have got through, but it would have been Jesus in powdered   wig and knee breeches. The Upanishad scribes did much the same thing: they made the original teachers talk like Brahmans, even when they were calling the Brahmans names. the odd result of this is that the original sages often appear as enthusiastic devotees of God (or rather, the gods, for the Brahmans had several), when, in fact, they did not believe in God at all. The sages thought that the whole Hindu pantheon was a clever invention of the priests to put money into their own pockets. They had no more use for God than did Karl Marx, but it should be added that they would have had no use for Karl Marx either. They did not set themselves up as prophets; they had no desire to put the world to rights. As far as they were concerned, the world could stew in its own juice. They taught no morality in fact, a close inspection of some passages in the Upanishads suggests that a follower of their philosophy could do pretty much as he pleased and still not commit a sin. These passages bring an embarrassed blush to the cheeks of Indian scholars even today: for Indians, who are proud of the fact that they were able to give the world the Upanishads, are a distinctly moral people. Consequently, Indian scholars politely misread the Upanishads for centuries. As for the rest of the world, it did not know that these books existed until the 19th  century, when the philosopher Schopenhauer discovered one of them, and confessed himself profoundly moved. He, too, misread the text, but it did not matter, since the Upanishad that so impressed him was a German forgery. It is only now, in the second half of the 20th century, when it is safe to be an atheist and to have dubious morals, that the true teachings of the sages are being bruited abroad. When the sages of the Upanishads first taught, Hindu civilisation was completely dominated by priests, as ours is by the tax-man. Like him, the priests had a finger in every pie. They had rules that had to be followed for every act in the daily round: they even went so far as to lay down minute instructions about the way a man must defecate and about how he should go to bed with his wife.The penalty for disobeying the priest was the displeasure of the gods, which could be fatal. Happily, the priest could turn away divine wrath if he chose to—for a fee. The sages taught that the first thing to do was to leave this preposterous society and retire to some quiet place that was free from priests. The next thing was to find out who you really are , Brahmans aside, parents aside. The result of some weeks, or even months, of this inquiry, they said, is that you do not find out who you are but you do realise, with a sense of shock, who you are not. (I know, because I have made the experiment.) You are not the person you have always thought you were, because that person has been constructed for you by others, by parents, wives, children, friends, lawmakers —the whole fabric of human society in which you have hitherto lived. With this discovery, you can go through your past in your mind's eye, peeling it away like the layers of an onion. In each layer you will find not yourself but the product of other people. When the last layer of an onion has been removed there is nothing left. This simile delighted the sages. They said it was exactly what you would find if you examined your own life—nothing. You do not find your true self, as you might have expected: you have destroyed yourself. You are now ready for the next step, described admirably by a contemporary guru, Bhagwan Shree Rajneesh, a middle-aged man with a great-domed, bald forehead and a remarkable gift for explaining difficult matters in simple terms. For the next step Bhagwan Shree Rajneesh asks you to hold a flower in your hand. Let me hasten to say that he is not leading you to the hippies. Any object will do, your watch, for instance. The point is to look at this   object and make no judgment about it: do not even say "It is beautiful." That, Rajneesh explains, is a judgment coming out of your past, and that past, as we have learned, is an illusion created by others. With constant practice at making no judgments. You will be able to look at the flower and be only aware of it. "Aware" is Rajneesh's word: good as it is, I am not sure that it really conveys the experience he wishes to describe, although it comes very near. If I may be allowed to try my hand at being an amateur guru, I would say that the sensation may be grasped, momentarily, by chancing upon something that is utterly incomprehensible. For example, I am the worst of mathematicians. But let us say that in the scientific section of a bookshop I idly take down a volume because it has the name of a famous nuclear physicist on the spine. I open it at random. I am faced by two pages of mathematical formulas, of which I understand not one symbol. I can see the print, but I can make no judgment about it. This blankness will pass rapidly. A part of my mind will insist on getting to work. I will think, "With this sort of thing the atom bomb was made," or I may think, "'Why was I always such a dunce at mathematics in school? I wish I had tried harder." But note that there have been two minds at work— the one that observed the page and the one that judged it. The sages of the Upanishads were interested in the first. The second, they said, caused all the trouble. It is a difficult saying. Clearly, anybody who would go in search of knowledge has considerable mental power. But the hardest thing for an intelligent man to do is to forget how intelligent he is. This, however, must be done, said the teachers. After a long experience of non-judgment, the mind (or the soul, the spirit, or what have you—the sages never   settled that question) suddenly transcends itself. It arrives at an immense tranquillity. You are no longer yourself, but a new being, free from all worldly contamination. The world, of course, is still there, and so are your other selves You survey them, but with a neutral eye. This is the aim of the sages, and the end of their teachings.   STATE OF TRANQUILLITY The sages spoke of this state of tranquillity with enthusiasm, and so has everyone else (including myself) who has experienced it, however briefly. (It is usually brief: the world reclaims you, but you return to it a different person.) Unfortunately, this attractive doctrine, when it was written down, met with a disaster: it became mixed up with yoga. Yoga is a much abused word. Employed with accuracy, it means any practice that will help you meditate. The Eightfold Path of Buddha is a very unexciting affair, but it can be called a yoga, and it is probably the sort of common sense advice that the original sages of the Upanishads gave their pupils. The yoga in which you tie your legs in complicated Oriental knots is hatha-yoga. Many people regard it as an advanced physical exercise. Such a clean and breezy view  is, unfortunately, untenable, for hatha-yoga has rather murky origins. When the Aryans first came into India they found the original inhabitants indulging in what were, to them, abhorrent religious practices. They kept themselves clear of these  practices, but they did not put an end to them. Nobody ever has. The earliest religion of  India survives to this day, and is known as the Tantric faith. On the one side Tantrism is a harmless   mixture of astrology and  voodoo. To see the otherside, let us take the figure of Gorkanath. His name is variously said   to mean Lord of Filth, or, alternatively, Cow-Eater, which to an orthodox Hindu  is much the same thing. He  lived about AD 1100 and founded a sect aimed at  flouting all conventions. This, of course, was admirable. But the actual  style of flouting was a more dubious matter. It included the eating of dead human bodies,scatological banquets, and all forms of sexual perversion prolonged to the utter exhaustion of the devotee. It also included hatha-yoga. Gorkanath wrote a treatise on the subject, now, perhaps fortunately, lost. The aim of all this hysteria was to equip the   devotee with supernatural powers. With these he could do evil or, if he chose, good to his fellow men. He could also work miracles, such as flying through the air, being in two places at once, and reading people's thoughts. The Gorkanath cult died, presumably from its own   excesses, and little of the sort   is found in India today. The more benign side of Tantrism barely survived,   and still has a few esoteric believers. What did not die, but positively nourished, was the belief that a holy man who   none through hatha- yoga and attained enlightenment also acquired supernatural powers. Many yogis believe this. One of the most charming of them is Sai Baba, a famous Indian guru who has an immense and awe-struck following. He is a middle- aged man with a long robe and an Afro haircut. He claims to be able to materialise objects from the air. His favorite miracle is waving his hand in the air (sportingly pulling back the sleeve of his robe) and producing a handful of holy ashes. He has been known to do this in the unlikely setting of Bombay's Rotary Club.He also produces gold rings, which he gives to selected visitors—a feat that  has done nothing to diminish the numbers of his believers. He also has a sense of humor. An American woman visited him, and he obliged her by materialising the customary gold ring out of thin air. It was set with red and green precious stones, in the traditional Indian fashion. The American woman was dumbfounded. She wore the ring for a while, but discovered that she did not like it. She firmly believed in Sai Baba's miraculous powers, but she was not so sure of his taste in jewellery. She felt that she could not take the ring off, but every time she looked at it, she very much wanted to. Soon she met Sai Baba again. With a sweet smile, hewaved his hand in the air and produced another ring, this time of a thoroughly Western design. There may be two opinions about Sai Baba's mystic powers, but there can be no doubt about his beautiful manners.To return to serious matters. By the time of the Middle Ages in India, the Upanishads, though revered, were seen to be in conflict with the Vedas, books that enshrined the fundamentals of the Hindu religion. Just as Saint Thomas Aquinas set out to resolve the contradictions in the Catholic faith, so philosophers arose in India who attempted to do the same thing for Hinduism, but at even greater length. The result was a body of philosophy known as the Vedanta, meaning "'the end of the Vedas." with a hint that it is also their climax. Vedanta needs a lifetime of study to understand, at the end of which the student should be left with the conviction that his whole lifetime was nothing but an illusion. The philosophers of the Vedanta, however, had a higher moral tone than the anarchists of the original Upanishads, so a great deal of respectable morality was added. If life was an illusion, it proved to be a remarkably bitter one for the Hindus. They were conquered first by the Moslems and then by the British. Most of the Moslem rulers despised Hinduism. The British rulers, with no exceptions, made not the slightest effort to understand what it was. This wooden lack of curiosity had one advantage: it left the Hindus in peace. But it was too much peace. The Hindu mind became stagnant. Religion became a ritual. Philosophers gave up reconciling the sacred books and concentrated on getting government jobs, being philosophical only when they failed. This somnolence lasted through most of the 19th century, until the Hindus were shaken out of it by one of the most appealing figures in Indian history. Narendranath Dutt, later known as Vivekananda, was a bright youth who was educated by Christian missionaries. He, too, would probably have ended up in a government job had he not met an extraordinary figure called Ramakrishna. Ramakrishna was a man whose religious zeal burned so intensely that he could summon up visions of the Hindu gods to whom he was devoted. This was, perhaps, to be expected. What was disconcerting was that by living temporarily as a Moslem, he could also summon up the Prophet Mohammed. After a further experience with visions of Jesus Christ, he began to preach that all religions were the same; all their prophets were God: God, indeed, was everywhere. He gave a striking demonstration of this belief by crowning his head with flowers and adoring himself. His fame spread. The father of the poet and later Nobel Prize winner Rabindranath Tagore did him the honor of asking him to lunch, but cancelled the invitation when Ramakrishna refused to wear anything but his exiguous loincloth. The young Vivekananda met him, and Ramakrishna, deeply impressed, would often fall into a trance at the mere sight of him. With this recommendation Vivekananda took to the religious life, touring all India. In 1893 a World's Parliament of Religions was scheduled in Chicago. The   Rajah of Ramnad, Vivekananda's native State, was a great admirer of the young man, and decided to send him to Chicago as the   representative of Hinduism. He supplied him with travelling expenses, a robe, and a large turban. American audiences were overwhelmed by Vivekananda's oratory, his commanding presence, and especially by his robe and turban. He was the immediate success of the conference. He preached a simplified version of Vedanta, and it is a measure of the power of his personality that he won over hundreds of Americans to this abstruse doctrine in a matter of weeks. Money poured in. He returned to India a hero, the first Indian to have made an impact on the Western world. His delighted rajah organised a welcome home procession of great magnificence. Choirs sang choruses from Handel's oratorios. Vivekananda was young; he was the most remarkable Indian of modern times until the emergence of Mahatma Gandhi: and he had a shock in store for his inert countrymen.

item.title: Understanding hinduism and mysticism part two
item.dc:creator: sanjeevnjha
item.content:encoded: CALL FOR MUSCLE Instead of telling them, as they expected, that Indians had a great inheritance of spiritual wisdom to give to the materialistic West, he asked them, pointedly, what they thought they were doing "squinting at the ends of your noses and saying 'Om.'" What he wanted, he said, was not willowy and prayerful disciples, but muscular young men who would put the country to rights. "You will understand the Gita all the better," he explained, '"if you have strong biceps." He added that non-violence was suicide. The true Vedantist was a fighting man. To drive home his point, while off Corsica he arranged a special ceremony in honor of its most famous son, Napoleon. He was ready with an explanation of these unexpected remarks, and the explanation was even more surprising. He said that he had been greatly impressed by the Americans. He admired their drive and their industry. He approved of their pragmatic materialism. He had no criticism of their pursuit of money. On the contrary, he told the Indians to study the actions of the Americans and do likewise. He undertook an exhausting tour of India preaching these opinions, in a blazing effort to arouse his countrymen. He died, burned out, at the age of 39. A massive bronze monument to him now stands in Bombay. Some of his sayings are inscribed on metal plates around it. Unfortunately, his most electric saying is not there. "Indians," he said, "get off your backsides!" It is still good advice. The Indians nowadays are trying to follow it: but after all those centuries of oppression they are feeling, they admit, a little stiff at the knees. Vivekananda was perfectly right in his view of Vedanta, though many Indians refused to believe it then, and still do. The aim of   a wise man should be release from himself by meditation. But when he is not meditating. he should perform his social duties as a citizen, a father, a husband, and even a soldier. As he grows older, and the more he meditates, these things will grow progressively dimmer. But until he has attained some measure of release, he should not use his meditations as an excuse for shirking.The hippies, who are to be seen all over India escaping from the West, are wrong. But then, more important people have been wrong, too. I myself have heard Gandhi reading the Baghavad Gita to thousands, in support of his belief in pacifism, which he carried to an extreme degree. The Gita is not a sacred book, but it is regarded as such by millions. Rather, it is the story, told in exquisite poetry, of how the god Krishna persuaded the warrior Arjun to go into battle and fight, even against his own relatives, this being something that, until he had heard Krishna out, Arjun shrank from doing. SPIRITUAL CONSOLATION When I was a boy in England, good, kindly, peace-loving people, often vegetarians, used to carry little editions of the Gita bound in limp leather, into which they would dip for spiritual consolation. Either the translations were false or their dipping was highly selective. But they may be forgiven. Anyone who sets out to study Hindu mysticism has some tough sledding ahead. Aware of this, the battalions of swamis and gurus who followed Vivekananda across the Atlantic sought a way to make things a little less confusing. Yoga was conveniently at hand. It was sufficiently odd to be Oriental (the disciple wore a mini-loincloth like Ramakrishna) and it catered to the Western man's taste for physical exercise. But it was a very mild version of hatha-yoga that the swamis taught. They remembered Ramakrishna's warning that hatha-yoga carried to its limits had nearly depraved him. None of these swamis and yogis had the charisma of Vivekananda, nor had they his cussedness and originality of mind. But the darker, not to say more ludicrous, side of hatha-yoga was at hand to supply the lack. Practitioners claimed it had given them supernatural powers. Speaking mysteriously of being able to be in two places at once, they nevertheless duly collected their steamship fares from the faithful. One, who set up a flourishing ashram on the West Coast, claims in his autobiography that, being late tor a train, he managed to stop it on its way out of the station through sheer spiritual force. Attendant disciples confirmed this remarkable feat. Had one doubting Thomas observed that the train might have stopped because the signal had turned from green to red, it would have done no good at all. Yogis of this particular ilk would have said with a smile that of course it did; changing the signal was part of the miracle. In the 1920s there came a change. The move toward Indian independence had begun and Gandhi was returning dignity to his people. Young Indian men attracted by their own culture, went back to the original texts. Most were still steeped in Western thought, but things had taken a fortunate turn for them. Freud, Jung, and others had sharpened the world's interests in the human mind and invented new techniques for exploring it. The analyst's couch had a great resemblance to the process of peeling away the onion. Physicists who were dealing with the ultimate particles of matter did not rule out the possibility that their researches might end up in something very near mysticism; the universe might well turn out to be all made of the same thing—a  collection of waves, for instance. That everything—gods, matter, and man—was of  the same substance was one of the key speculations of the Upanishads. A new type of swami arose, modest, well-informed, and, above all, honest. The doyen of these swamis is Krishnamurti. A beautiful young man when he began, he is now a beautiful old man living in a slum quarter of Rome. In between he has been many things. At first he was a sort of modern Vivekananda with an instant following. When he refused to work miracles, his admirers invented them for him: feats such as speaking in English and being magically understood by listeners who knew only different tongues. Passing beyond this, Krishnamurti began to teach the bare essentials of the Upanishads, but with such grace and charm that his listeners forgot their disappointment that he obstinately refrained from rising three feet in the air. As he matured, his dislike for the faithful increased, but so did his grasp of the plain truth. Today, he has the starkest of all things to say. People still come to Krishnamurti to ask his method of seeking release and enlightenment. He tells them there is no method. They ask him for guiding rules, and he says there are no rules. He sums up his teaching in two words: "Drop it." "It," in this lapidary phrase, means everything.   In other words, the whole technique of attaining release is to divest one's self of every interest in the world, and that can best be done by simply doing it. Other new mystics of equal intelligence but without Krishnamurti's long experience are critical of this. They admire him. but they say that what might be easy for him is difficult for lesser people. They sum it up by saying, "He is right, but wrong." People need some sort of help to put them on the path of meditation. Bhagwan Shree Rajneesh says that this might be anything: you may sing, you may recite poetry, you may dance. He then goes on to explain, with great penetration, that it must be something that you do not do very well. If you are an excellent dancer, dancing will be no good because you will be thinking of your dancing, whereas the whole object of the exercise is to put you into a state in which you are doing no thinking at all. This (and it is often forgotten) is the aim of all meditation. The practice of some useful routines has been explored by the swamis of the Hare Krishna cult, which has spread throughout the world. Hindu ritual is a very simple affair, designed for a largely illiterate people. The worship of the gods is done by doing little dance steps, chanting some verses over and over again, and clashing small cymbals to the beat of a drum. Anybody can do it: it would be absurd to do it well. But the ritual has proved to be useful in taking the mind off mundane worries. One unexpected result of this is that people addicted to hard drugs find they have less and less dependence upon them, and some give them up entirely. There is no question about this: I have talked to many ex-addicts, and there is no doubt that they are telling the truth. I would add two reservations: those cured are mostly young, and their previous addiction seems mainly to have started with a desire to keep up with their companions.It is also worth remarking that the gurus and swamis they meet have no moral objection to drug-taking at all. Very few Indians have. At any rate, we have the spectacle, in India and all over the world, of people going around the streets in saffron robes dancing a hoppity dance step, beating cymbals, and chanting in Sanskrit. They have no right to the robe (it is the mark of an adept), and their Sanskrit pronunciation is very funny. This is fine, say the gurus: they shouldn't try to be better at it. In fact, with luck they won't try to be better at anything. The new mystics are often dubious about being called gurus. The word means a teacher and guide. But just as it is common for a person undergoing psychoanalysis to fall in love with the psychiatrist, so a person undertaking meditation is inclined to fling himself upon his teacher in an ecstasy of obedience. He pesters him for advice on the smallest matters, as well as those vital to himself. The new mystics cannot avoid this: but most of them state very carefully that they cannot give advice—the seeker after release is on his own. THE NEW MYSTICS The new Indian mystics are, by and large, a free and easy lot. They have something for everyone. Swami Chinmayananda, for instance, appeals to the intellectuals. He does little more than expound the Hindu texts, but he does this in so lucid a way that in 1971 he attracted ten thousand people a night in the hot Bombay summer. His great merit is that when there is a contradiction in his sources (and there are many), he faces the issue squarely. He makes no claim to be a superior human being — no more claim, that is, than the average professor of philosophy in most Western universities. Swami Satchidananda appeals to those who need a father figure. He has a kind face and a grey beard, as well as endearing traits like not being able to do his own cooking. His teaching, which is elementary, is much the same as the others. At the opposite extreme is Swami Bhaktivedanta. the head of the Hare Krishna movement. This sect is meant for people who have religious leanings and who find a certain peace of mind in simple rituals. Curiously enough, it is this movement that most attracts followers from the West. This brings us, finally, to Maharshi Yogi. This is his real name. The West has corrupted it into "Maharishi," meaning "great rishi," for rishis were sages who lived in remote places,   undergoing severe austerities. Maharshi Yogi, need I say, is not one of these. It is impossible to imagine a true rishi who giggles—and    Maharshi Yogi would not be himself if he didn't. He gained notoriety when the Beatles went to him for advice. They told him their troubles, which were   multitudinous. Maharshi Yogi listened, and giggled. This was a new sound to these much- flattered young men, though   not the new sound they   desperately needed. They left in a towering huff. Yet of all the contemporary swamis, "Maharishi"   Yogi represents most clearly   what the Upanishads are about. It is well known that he makes his journeys in a private aircraft. This is perfectly in accord with the texts. Not only can   he use an airplane, but he could even make love to the   hostess if he chose, without   offending the canon. The Upanishads explicitly   state that a man, having meditated and found release, can return to the world and   (as they say) "enjoy chariots and women." Such a man will probably look upon both  with amused detachment, and that is exactly how Maharshi Yogi looks upon the world.

item.title: Mystery Of Will Novel First Chapter
item.dc:creator: sanjeevnjha
item.content:encoded: Day 1 Bangalore 5:00 PM Gautam’s apartment   Twenty seven year old Gautam is sitting in a beanbag staring at his laptop. An ashtray full of cigarette butts is on the floor. He is smoking and looking at his MacBook screen. He is watching his second movie of the day. In short, he is following his usual routine and that means sleeping, smoking and watching movies downloaded from pirate bay. The doorbell rings and startles him. He is not expecting anyone.   No one visits him these days. Amrita is the only regular visitor and she never rings the bell. Gautam is not expecting her today after their fight last evening.   He does not bother getting up. Most likely it is the security guard to collect water bill or deliver electricity bill. Not worth the effort. The bell rings again and that irritates him. Now he has to deal with it. He gets out of the beanbag with a huge effort and opens the door. Someone in a black suit and French beard is at the door. This gentleman is around fifty, short and is carrying a small briefcase in his hands. Gautam scanned his memory but could not locate the face. He had the door open and he was just staring at the gentleman. The gentleman took the initiative.   Hi, Are you Gautam? Yes, I am Mr. Gautam, My name is Ashwin Saxena. I am an advocate in the Saxena and Saxena law firm of Mumbai. Was Mr. Anil Kumar your father? That is correct. Are you a Kashmiri Brahman?   Yes. Please excuse my rudeness but do we know each other?   Well Mr. Gautam, not personally but I have some really important things to discuss. Our firm is in Mumbai and I have come to Bangalore today just to discuss your case. If it helps, I got your address from your company in Eco Tech Park. I went there first. Gautam thought for a moment. The movie had to wait. This guy has come from Mumbai. Let me just get it over with.   Gautam invited advocate Ashwin inside his apartment. Gautam lives in a small six hundred square feet apartment. From the door you can see the bedroom on you right hand side. The kitchen is in front of the door.  Whatever space is between the kitchen, the door and bedroom is called living room.   There were two beanbags and a coffee table in the living room. Advocate Ashwin walked in and stared helplessly at the beanbag. Gautam understood. He got his only chair from the bedroom and placed it near the beanbag.  Advocate Ashwin sat on the chair. Gautam took his usual place, the black beanbag. Advocate Ashwin opened his briefcase and took out a notebook.  After flipping through some pages, he said,  ”Your grandfather and grandmother were separated after seven years of marriage? “   Gautam replied with surprise in his voice, “Yes. Very few people know that. How come you know all this?”   Advocate Ashwin smiled and dropped another bomb. “After divorce, your grandmother left Kashmir with your father and settled in Bangalore?   Gautam was shocked. Why you are asking all these questions? You know things about my family that very few do.   Advocate Ashwin took out a photo from his briefcase and gave it to Gautam. Gautam was surprised to see that the person in the photograph looked just like him.   He asked advocate Ashwin,” Who is this person? “   Advocate Ashwin replied with a smiling face, Gautam, You are looking at your grandfather.   Oh! Where is he now?   The expression on advocate Ashwin’s face changed. He said in a grave tone, your grandfather died last week. Our firm is in charge of executing his will. Normally we do not take such requests but the pressure came from quite high up. Your grandfather's will is not about documents or certificates or any material possession.  The sole heir gets one envelope after his death.   Mr. Ashwin, did the will mention my name and address? There is no confusion Mr. Gautam. Your grandfather's will mentions you as the beneficiary and it had your company address. The reply shocked Gautam but he managed to keep a straight face.   Advocate Ashwin took out one gray envelope and one form with revenue stamp from his briefcase.  Mr. Gautam Please take this envelope and just sign my custody form. This envelope is your property and I am sorry for asking all those questions. It was just a routine legal stuff to verify you as your grandfather’s rightful heir. Personally, I was convinced the moment I saw your face.  Now my job is done.   Gautam signed the form and took the envelope. He put the envelope on the coffee table.   Gautam asked ” where was my grandfather at the time of his death?”   Advocate Ashwin said, "He settled in Nepal after leaving India. He was respected a lot there. You can say, a rich big name. His lavish parties were the talk of the town. Last year he invited our boss to his place. There he gave him this envelope.   Gautam - How can you be so sure that he was rich at the time of his death?   Advocate Ashwin said, our fees for transferring this envelope to you is one crore rupees. We specialize in wills and probate services. We are the best firm in Mumbai and usually only the old Parsis can afford us. If he had that kind of money then he must be rich.   The words “one crore” hit Gautam hard. He continued to stare at Advocate Ashwin. Advocate Ashwin said,” My job is finished here. I will take your leave now as I have a return flight with Indigo at 8:35. But I will advice you not to ignore the envelope and its contents. After all, your grandfather paid us one crore to deliver this. It must have something very important. Gautam nodded in agreement. " I will take a look at what is inside the envelope. Can you also please check your records and confirm that this envelope was indeed sent by my grandfather?"   Advocate Ashwin smiled. Mr. Gautam, The reason your grandfather paid such amount was to ensure that the envelope is entrusted to right people at every stage.  Maybe you should just Google our firm Saxena and Saxena in Mumbai. I will leave my email with you. If you have any other queries just send me a mail.   Advocate Ashwin got up from the chair. Gautam asked if he would like some coffee but Advocate Ashwin was in a hurry to catch his return flight. Gautam saw him to the door. They said their goodbyes and Gautam closed the door.   Gautam came back to the coffee table and looked at the envelope. People get money and property when their grand fathers die. All he got was an envelope. Considering his recent run of luck it sure won't have the code to a Swiss bank account.   He was fairly certain that whatever else he may have had, he certainly did not have luck.   He took the envelope in his hand and studied it carefully. It was a 6-inch by 4-inch envelope made of hard paper. It had nothing written on the front side. He turned it and the backside had what looked like a date written on it, 14/03/10->, Nothing else, just 14/03/10-> on the backside in blue ink. Maybe it was the date when the envelope was handed over to the law firm. Gautam went to his study table in bedroom, sat down and took out a paper knife from the penholder.   Gautam started to open the envelope very slowly with the paper knife. Once done, he shook the envelope on study table. What came out of the envelope surprised him. There was a folded paper and a strange looking key. He first looked at the key. It was a strange looking key. It was made of metal and heavy. It had a slender tube at the end much like a tubular key instead of a blade. However the tube did not end in a bow.   Between the bow and tube there was a square bracket. One side of the square bracket had notches coming out on top like the tooth of a regular key. The bow of this key was rectangular.  It was very difficult to ascertain what kind of a lock that key can open. Gautam has not seen any key like that in his life.   The feel of the key was heavy. It must have been made in the old days. Gautam rotated the key in his hand and put it down.  Next, he turned his attention to the paper. He unfolded it slowly and pressed it against the table. He moved his table lamp over the paper and started reading it.   Dear Grandson,   I hope you have grown up well. I am enclosing a riddle. This riddle will help you find the location of a treasure.   “Source of the message line that has eyes.” “ASB/chapter-8 near Dead CM”   My best wishes,   - Your grandfather     What kind of a grandfather spends one crore rupees and leaves such cryptic message and a weird key to his sole heir? What sense can he make out of this message?   Did his grandfather lost his marbles and wrote that letter as a practical joke? Maybe his last hurrah! Maybe he should have just sent me one crore instead of giving it to that stupid firm in Mumbai.   What are ASB and dead CM? What message line has eyes? Which locks will this weird key open?   Gautam felt irritated. This was one of destiny's cruel jokes. He thought of leaving the riddle for the moment. He will take a look again when he is in good mood.  He put the envelope and key in drawer. He walked back to the living room and his beanbag. He opened his laptop and hit play on VLC player.  Now the movie had moved to a nightclub. There was a guy on stage shouting, "No Hay Banda, There is no Band". The two ladies in the movie were cowering in their seats.   Oh No! This is really one of those neo-noir movies. Today I am not supposed to enjoy a movie also. He closed the lid of his MacBook and stretched himself on the beanbag. He was thinking about the events of last 15 minutes and staring at the ceiling. Sure, it has to make some sense.   From what he knew, his grandfather was quite talented and a most extraordinary person. Advocate Ashwin had also confirmed his tall status in Nepalese society. Sure, the letter has to mean something. Maybe it is something very simple. Maybe the key opens some locker in Nepal and the letter is simply some substitution cipher or a book cipher.   His grandfather may have had a penchant for mystery and just added some twist. Maybe he can just Google the keywords and see what comes up. He kept on staring. He was feeling tired. He felt that the acuteness of his mind was gone after working for four years in Indian software Industry.  Maybe he would have cracked this in college in 15 minutes or could have found some one to do it.   Finally, he made up his mind. Maybe this is simple and just requires him talking to someone. He thought of Amrita. Maybe she can make his mind work by irritating him. She always managed to irritate him. He was absolutely sure that he does not want to talk to her. He sent her an SMS.
